reviewText:
Do you like stoning fish-men to death with big rocks?  I know I do!  But if you're like me, it's a private pleasure and no one must know.  So you creep out at night, ducking behind cover, keeping low to the ground, slowly rotating your irregular bit of rock (sedimentary perhaps), finding the grip to put the perfect english on it, listening for the hop-hop sounds of the fish-man as you slowly peak out, glancing briefly to see that his dopey face is turned away revealing his moist, tender cranium...

What was I talking about?  Oh, yeah, Eldritch.  It's pretty good.

No, scratch that, Eldritch is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ miracle.  Procedural generation and permadeath, the marks of the roguelike genre are two things that used to send me running like I'm trying to outrun my fat, juicy friend, who is also trying to outrun some squamous monster from the primordial deep.  But somehow the dark wizards behind Eldritch managed to create the perfect combination of play to reach all the way deep into this previously forbidden zone of mine.  Well, that got weird.

Anyway, what does Eldritch do so right?  Well, it allows you to move in the least efficient way possible!  Crouching low to the ground to move slow and silent, sliding from a run, peeking around corners while still counting as being behind the corner, jumping and pulling yourself onto ledges you can't quite clear (i.e. mantling).  Those up on their gaming history might recognize these as the controls for the early Thief games and any game that has them and implements them correctly gives me a stiffy.

Next, the game traps you in a nightmarish loop from which you can never escape... something, something, profit?  When you die, resurrecting is only a click away, ensuring that you can get right back into the fray armed with new knowledge that may save your dumb ♥♥♥ next time.  The game also takes a bit of the edge off the permadeath by allowing you to store artifacts (the game's currency and fuel for your magic) in banks that will carry over if you die.

And the in-game map is brilliant.  Really?  I'm trying to sell you a game based on its in-game map?  Yes, I am bloody-well trying to sell you a game based on an in-game map!  The procedural generation works nicely, never feeling like you're being led nowhere.  Every square on the map has something to reward your exploration and the map I just touted comunicates it to you brilliantly.  The map doesn't show you fine details, but simply breaks the dungeon into a leveled grid, marking off which squares you've been to and if they contain a major feature.  You couldn't ask for a better companion in seeking out forbidden items spewing particle effects for you to get your sticky human hands on.

Finally, the main game is just the right length.  Doing a patient stealthy run, you can easily finish in about three/four hours.  You'll definitely feel incentive to be careful once you make progress, but every death will make you feel like you're one more corpse in the pile you can climb to victory rather than feeling like you've just graduated college only to light yourself on fire.

And that's just the main game.  Eldritch also includes two complete scenarios that lesser games would call DLC and charge you for.  One simulates a cocaine and dynamite fueled rampage through an asylum to bust souls out of the walls and escape to safety before a cosmic horror chases you down and eats you.  This mode will teach you that berserker raging your way through your problems is a perfectly valid solution in Eldritch, even if the stealth is so strong you just want to smear tanning butter on its pecs.  Also included is a long endurance dungeon to test your stealth skills with tough foes, few resources, and no trips back to safety for a breather like are found periodically in the main game.

As for the overall aesthetic and treatment of HP Lovecraft's work?  This game was made with love.  Love for unfathomable abominations from beyond the stars that just want to dissect your brain and stick it in a jar.  As Lovecraft fans know, old Howard P. spent a lot of time dealing with the intangibles of cosmic horror where terror comes from not being able to percieve or understand vast entities to which you are little more than the dirt beneath their heels.  He also wrote schlocky adventure stories about explorers fighting monsters and zombies and ♥♥♥♥.  Eldritch pulls off the balance nicely.

Most of the enemies you face will be out of Lovecraft's more tangible gallery, but even with the Minecrafty graphics and squishy fish-men, the indestructible monsters like the Shoggoth and Yog Sothoth feel amorphous and dangerous.  You won't spend too long looking at them because you'll be running the ♥♥♥♥ away.  The bigger cosmic" side is represented in the minimal story told only at the beginning and end with text boxes.  You can't represent that sort of thing visually and Eldritch knows well enough not to try
date: but rest assured it's there and you will confront it along with your seeming immortality.  And on the note of knowing what you can't do visually
recommended: Eldritch makes up for it with it's awesome sound design.  The Minecraft look might be a little too goofy to be horrifying
hoursPlayed: but damn if the sounds don't manage to freak my ♥♥♥♥ out.\n\nThere are few indie games that I think are worth their normal asking price.  I'll admit

At that point, I realized that the elements I'd loved so much were not appealing upon replay. reviewText:
Eldritch is a lightweight but fun action-roguelike with a Lovecraftian theme.

Eldritch is a roguelike, but it's a surprisingly easy one-- I finished the game for the first time after only about 7 or 8 total hours of play. Certain strategies make completion much easier, and the most difficult level out of the four is the second one. Since you can take the levels on in whatever order you like, you can optimize your playthrough to make beating the second level easier. If you're used to recent commerical roguelikes like The Binding of Isaac, The Dungeons of Dredmor, and others, Eldritch may seem very lightweight, very easy, and kind of simplistic. The bizarre difficulty curve-- with the second level being so much harder than even the secret fourth level-- may also be a bit of a disappointment.

Nevertheless, it's fun, well-made, and a good way to entertain yourself for 8 hours or less. The simple art is charming in its own way, and exploring to find your favorite strategies and item synergies is certainly entertaining.

reviewText:
I don't think I've had this large a change of heart on a game in a long while. Going into Eldritch, I lost hope almost immediately. A combination of mediocre voxel environments, cartoonish bad guys, goofy sound effects, and stab-happy gameplay just didn't really jive with the whole Lovecraftian aesthetic it claimed to be rocking. Thirty minutes in I'd realized I'd come across pretty much every item I was going to see. An hour in and I'd conquered the first world, having at no time felt threatened by anything I faced. I entered world 2 for a few minutes, finding more of the same. Apart from my grudging admiration for the simple-yet-effective 3D minimap the game uses, I came to the conclusion that there was nothing here worth playing any further for. Bored and angry, I set the game aside for a while, wondering why anyone would publish so straightforward and sloppy a first-person shooter and decide to slap a Lovecraft theme on it.

Coming back to it on a whim, I re-entered world 2 and dug a little deeper. Suddenly, things were different. The difficulty spiked up nicely, adding opponents that required actual strategy, that I couldn't just flail wildly at and never worry about again, that left me feeling more than a little nervous. And then I died, though I'm not exactly sure how. I rushed back in, suddenly stripped of all my magic armaments and life boosts, and last less than half as long. Eventually, I figured out what's going on, learned how to dodge the traps, realized that stealth and discretion are actually necessary to survive, and on I went to a fun, twitchy, jumpy run through the rest of this Eternal Darkness / Spelunky / Minecraft hybrid. It's not terribly deep; as I said earlier, you find the vast majority of the items you'll ever see in level 1, and while the monsters do evolve over time, there's not a huge amount of variety here. Oftentimes, new monsters will simply be beefier and shoot faster, but there's enough weirdness thrown in to keep the game fresh. Also, be aware that this is in fact a roguelike. Dying sets you back to the start with just short of all your progress erased, but thankfully this is a game which rewards knowledge every bit as much as it does lots of ammo and a pair of stealth boots.

Don't go into this expecting any kind of dignified cosmic horror experience. It's sloppy, it's fun, and it's got some nice retro vibes to it hearkening back to the first person shooters of yore. If you're not sure if Eldritch is going to be for you, gauge your reaction to the phrase, Cthulhu vs. the Ninja Assassin." If that mental image doesn't ♥♥♥♥ you off
recommended: here's your chance to see it in action."

reviewText:
The minecraft-esque graphics turned me off from the game initially. But as I discovered that it was a rogue-like in a Lovecraftian setting, my interest was piqued.

I've played and beaten the game--a few times. Aspects of it were frustrating for me, as it seems it has been for most people. But I enjoy the gameplay. You are rewarded for whatever actions you take. Rush through a level? You are rewarded with progression. Rely upon stealth? You are rewarded with safety. Spend a lot of time searching around? You are rewarded with tons of resources and powers that can aid you in a time of need. Manage your resources properly? You can save a little bit for your next run, and you can easily progress and bypass challenges. This game rewards your playing style, no matter what it is. There is more than one way to progress.

This game, in truth, doesn't have a lot to do with Lovecraft. It is more of a back-drop for the gameplay. If you are looking for a real Lovecraftian experience, it might be best to pass up on this game. But if you're looking for a fun experience with a spice of something familiar, it's always nice to run screaming from a shoggoth who seems to follow you everywhere.

reviewText:
The last few years have seen a huge influx of Roguelikes, games that feature permadeath and heavily randomized elements. Roguelike FPSes are few and far between, so finding a good one is a rare treat. Eldritch is just that, inspired by the works of Lovecraft and pitting you against dungeons of lurking horrors. It started out solid and has only grown moreso over time, thanks to the continuing efforts of its single developer.

Eldritch plops you into a mysterious library full of books that spirit you away to unearthly dungeons. The main game is three books linking to dungeons holding the souls of elder gods. Once you find the soul in one dungeon, the book to the next opens up. Each dungeon is three areas with three floors each, split into randomized chunks and scattered with items and enemies. You'll find artifacts that work as both currency and spellcasting reagents, weapons like knives and guns and dynamite, equippable gear that gives you very useful abilities, and altars that teach you new spells. These tools will help you navigate the floors and deal with the host of unsavory types trying to stop you from claiming the souls.

Despite the cosmic horror backdrop, Eldritch works best as an action game. The movement of your character is reminiscent of older games like Quake, letting you slide around at inhuman speeds. The enemies are a mixed bag, with some like the frogmen and cultists being little more than cannon fodder. You will encounter others like relentless, all-consuming shoggoths and tall creatures that cannot be killed that will complicate your travels and send shivers up your spine. Each book has a clever cross-section of foes that form a confounding package and demand stealth and caution. Some can be frustrating before you learn how to deal with them, but the challenge is well-balanced.

The enemies are the real source of fear and tension in the game, despite their cartoony appearance. A lot of games have tried to ape the look and feel of Minecraft, but Eldritch pulls it off well, imparting the same dread that skeletons and creepers do in tight spaces. The block grid nature of the levels can help you space your jumps and keep your bearings, and there are even tools for breaking through walls and creating new blocks. The sound design is minimal, and while a few of the ambient enemy noises don't work you will learn to dread those of the more troublesome foes.

In addition to the three main dungeons, there's an extended ice-themed dungeon based on At the Mountains of Madness, and a timed score-attack mode set in a hellish asylum. The developer added both of these post-launch, and continued to re-tune the game to great effect. I played Eldritch back when it launched and it is an even better game now, with more threatening enemies and better balance. As a Roguelike, an FPS, and even a horror game, I can earnestly recommend this one.

reviewText: A highly delicious and aesthetically pleasing stealth Rogue-like" FPS mash-um-up. I'm particularly fond of good gameplay and Eldritch definitely delivers. It has character. It has atmosphere. It has giant tentacle blobs that phase through openings and chase you down until you're crying for more bullets!\n\nOn the surface it may appear rather dullishly action packed repetitive nonsense
date:
but the simplicity and attention to detail is what makes titles like Eldritch so awesome. There's a high degree of insanity to be had in a hundred different scenarios if you are willing to reach into your creative coffers and pull out a magic rabbit.

There are times when you've out-maneuvered and out-brained a few dozen baddies and start wondering where the challenge lies only to slip on a broken tile and be man handled by a couple of living statues that certainly have nothing but sinister intentions.

You ressurect and steel yourself for another run only to realize it's even MORE difficult in deprivation of your gadgets and fancy schwahza (Props if you get the reference). How to continue but change your playstyle to suit your capabilities?

By challenging you to use your smarts in one wickedly strange environment that increases in difficulty you get a definite "edge of your seat" feeling at almost every moment.

Highly captivating in almost every way

reviewText:
The visual aesthetic in this game is very similar to that of Minecraft, but it doesn't at ALL take away from the spooky atmosphere. In fact the graphical simplicity is oddly easy on the eyes, and allows you to absorb the eerie ambiance and the minimal - but still great - soundtrack without being completely oggled by flashy visuals. It goes to show you don't need the most advanced graphical engine to make a solid horror game.

Eldritch is genuinely creepy, and outright terrifying once you run into your first Shoggath. Or four. Like I did. It really is an unnerving and fun game, and captures the feeling of helplessness and paranoia that Lovecraft is so famous for.

Plus the Shopkeepers are Fishmen in cute little bow ties, and a Shoggath in a giant Bowler Hat. Its surprisingly adorable and I love it.

reviewText: Eldritch is the sort of game I would easily recommend to anyone, because I think just about anyone could have fun with it.  Like shooting things?  Play Eldritch.  Like sneaking around?  Play Eldritch.  Like setting traps?  Play Eldritch.  Like navigating mazes?  Play Eldritch.  Don't like navigating mazes?  Play Eldritch.  I can't imagine anyone not getting at least some enjoyment out of it.  Look past its homespun visuals and simple mechanics and you'll find a sophisticated experience that's best described as Dishonored seen through the lens of Binding of Isaac, written by H.P Lovecraft, with Minecraft's makeup and wardrobe, and a little sprinkle of adorable terror.  If that doesn't sell the game to you, I don't know what will.\n\nRead more here[videogamepotpourri.blogspot.com]

reviewText:
A first person action game inspired by Lovecraft, you’re stuck in a strange world, starting off in a library filled with books that can transport you to ever stranger worlds. With fish-lipped people. Because why not.

Graphically the game takes a lot of cues from Minecraft, working in a highly cubic fashion, and with the right items you can even destroy or place blocks, although you never reach the point of actual crafting. The whole game is focused around exploration, survival, and eventual escape of the madhouse that is this universe.

Then you die, and you get sent to an ACTUAL asylum.

The Minecraft-style graphics are pretty decent, the sound design is acceptable, but the gameplay, whilst it works, runs the risk of becoming repetitive before long, if there aren’t more items introduced at some point than what we saw thus far.

Still, not a bad title all round!

reviewText: A game that presents you with everything you need from the start, and casually waits for you to learn its rules. It's a really refreshing time, and a pretty player friendly entry point into the roguelike/immersive sim genre. Levels are procedurally generated, but work from established tile sets that lead to familiar feeling levels; despite their randomized nature. It never feels unfair. The progression curve just feels really great. Definitely check this game out.

reviewText: As a fan of Lovecraft's writing, this was a surprise gem. Minecraft-based first-person exploration and survival set in the Cthulhu Mythos universe. You find yourself waking in a strange old library and have to examine several magical tomes to find a way to escape. Each book is a portal to a different world and contains an orb that traps the soul of an Old One, which can be used to unlock further books.\n\nEach world is based on the works of Lovecraft (ie. a winter-set world to the tune of At the Mountains of Madness") and include roaming terrors from the inspired story. You can find a variety of weapons with which to defend yourself (or take a stealth approach if you prefer) and several utility tools to help you better get around. As you proceed you also collect "artifacts"
date: which act as the game all-purpose currency. You can use artifacts to pay for in-store items or power abilities.\n\nGreat level design

reviewText:
It's sad to see that this gem was lost in a dark heap of indie games, part of which isn't subject to comparison.
I very much like H. P. Lovecraft's works, so, this game is impregnated by the interesting themes for me.
Fishman,Cultist,Lizard,penguin...dark atmosphere,magnificent and atmosferic ost,difficulty,speed...
Speed in this game surprises me, not because I am playing from first person, just because
the speed of gameplay is increasing by in process of your skill growing.
Try to beat this game with clamping Shift and jumping all the time, it's interesting feeling I say.
This game taught me that dynamite is my best friend, and that dynamite can always open a passage for you everyplace where you want to go.
Oh god...somebody making weird sound...IN MY HOUSE!
Okay, this review ia over, I have to go and worship the great ǫ͜͏g̶̶̢̛a͠ḑ͡i͞n̴̡͜...
In conclusion, this game is worth the paid, and I want to see MOAR games like this in the future.

reviewText: Eldritch perfectly captures the strange worlds of HP Lovecraft. Chosen graphical stylisation suits here, between pixels, my imagination fills the gaps, it invokes images of unknown terrors and alien landscapes. Eerie sound design gives this game another (otherworldly) dimension, i was so drawn in, that i tried to look beyond corners from my chair :) Danger of permadeath only heightens the immersion, it coerced me to give my best on every try - to hide from monsters, search every corner for useful items and avoid deadly traps. Eldritch truly evokes sense of wonder and dread, as the player explores these strange and unknown worlds.\n

reviewText: I beat this game after 2 hours and I see no reason to play it again. It just has too little content, there's no character progression, there's barely any items to use. You will find daggers and guns (specifically a revolver) everywhere, I used them the whole game. While there is very few additional weapons, they are one time use for example bottles and dynamite. The problem here is that you can only have 2 weapons on you so if you want to pick up a dynamite you have to get rid of either the gun or the dagger and that is not something you want to do. Since the gun has limited ammunition and the dagger has no range.\n\nThere's just so little stuff in the game. You will have pretty much the exact same experience whenever you start a new game since you will use the same weapons and there's no class/leveling system or anything to make your character unique.

reviewText: A bland and derivative dungeon crawler with a millimeter-thin veneer of Lovecraft glued on top. Uses only the most superficial elements of his mythos as window dressing for a game that could just as easily use a generic fantasy or sci-fi setting. The source material does nothing to inform or shape the core gameplay, and this game could easily be retextured to any number of themes without any detrimental effect. Entertaining for upwards of half an hour, before you realize how shallow the game's sytems really are. For a game that actually does some of Lovecraft's ideas justice instead of merely paying them lip service, I recommend Eternal Darkness.

reviewText: A Cthulu mythos inspired advenutre with rouge-like elements that will pretty much dictate your enjoyment of the game. Procedurally generated levels will challenge and almost certainly frustrate you; since you lose all of your progress upon death. Despite it's Minecraft-like graphics which leaves some monsters looking silly or even cute game can be creepy and downright stressful at times. This is mostly due to it's great sound design that will teach you to listen and identify what enemies are shuffling, wailing, thumping or snoring in the next room even before you see them. Risk/reward gameplay agumented by locked secret rooms that may or may not have some crucial health or ammo, and shrines that will give you spells powered by artifact you can collect around levels combine to create a stressful, disheartening experience that remains true to it's source of inspiration even though It did occasionally left me feeling like I'm just repeating the endless cycle of dying and resurrecting until I get that perfect level setup.\nHowever, despite how many times I got killed by a dodgy platforming section literally two feet before the game ending, there was always a presence of that I can't quit now. This game will not break me !" feeling. Definite reccomendation if you like rouge-likes and Lovecraft."

reviewText:
Eldritch is a first-person stealth roguelike.
That said, the stealth aspect is optional, fighting things head-on or making a mad dash for the exit is just as valid.
Everything's carefully crafted and tuned so the game feels like a scarier Spelunky.
Yes, it's scary. Don't let the blocky graphics fool you, Eldritch is very unsettling thanks to its sound design and and enemy behaviour. You're always a few mistakes away from death, you can see and hear them, it makes you want to hide and never get out of your corner, but you need to proceed and face them.
However, as you learn enemy behaviours and feel more competent, you'll also feel safer and more in control. Each of the 5 levels starts out terrifying and becomes familiar with practice.

reviewText: This game is a fun game for those who like action games with a challenging difficulty and for fans of H. P. Lovecraft. As a fan of both, I enjoy the gameplay of Eldritch as the graphics have a retro yet updated feel to them that makes the game more appealing for me personally. It's a fun action game that combines the challenge of puzzles in fighting enemies taken straight from the mind of Lovecraft with level names such as Nyarlathotep, it really is a unique game. Highly reccommended for all.

reviewText:
Don't let the visuals fool you. This game is creepy!

You don't need to be stealthy, but believe me, caution it's your best choice.

What's around the corner? Don't be afraid to take a sneak peek. It's better you find the monsters before they find you. Enemies can hear your steps and follow you all the time. They even can open doors, so you'll never be safe. Also, you'll do everything to don't die. Every life matters.

All in all, Eldritch it's a game to be played slowly. Keep in mind that there's not much action here. Instead, there's a lot of tense moments and a great feeling of satisfaction when you can finish a stage alive.

How long can you survive in this hostile world?

reviewText: A proceedurally generated, Lovecraft-themed, first-person action rpg. Elderitch has an engaging retro 3d art style and great sound design. The stealth action gameplay feels great. Enemies are varied and interesting. The large levels have impressive geometry and are very atmospheric, and also fun to explore. Environments are fully destructible (which is an awesome yet underused game mechanic). There is an impressive amount of content here, including free DLC, secret endings, and a new game plus mode. This is a spectacular game, one of my favoites - buy it full price.

reviewText:
Eldritch is the kind of game that makes me wish I had a 'noncommittal gesture' button between the Yes and No buttons.

It's definitely got something going on between its muted slap-happy adorableness and Lovecraftian horror aesthetic. I like the way the game presents no clear-cut solution to the problems the Lovecraftian Theme Park makes you suffer through, but at the same time it's easy to collect a bunch of upgrades and turn the game into The Adventures of Catherine McGunhaver, Kicker of Cthulhu Faces. It's pretty easy to win (so I've been told, I can't quite grab all the orbs in one life which is pretty much grounds for invalidating my video game cred), so you may end up coasting through the game with your abilities, kicking Cthulhu Faces and listening to the ghost of H.P. Lovecraft scream in anguish as you put bullets through his life's work.

But at the same time, I can't help but feel this game's a bit insubstantial. The developers have been pretty good at releasing new content (see: The Mountains of Madness and the recent Asylum updates), but I've felt like I've seen everything three hours in. Worlds are limited to three levels with orbs to find at the end to unlock the final level or whatever, and I think you have to get them all without dying. The game has severe difficulty spikes - you can pretty much coast through the first world and expect the entire game to be like that right up until one of those ♥♥♥♥ing Weeping Angel lizards eats your ♥♥♥♥ing face, and even then that's the most difficult thing about the whole playthrough.

I guess Eldritch hasn't quite clicked with me, mainly because I've been walking around putting bullets through anything that looks at me funny and throwing beer bottles at all the acolytes milling around the dungeons like a frat boy on Spring Break at ♥♥♥♥sticks University. It requires a softer touch when I just want to walk around and kill everything. I'm not going to fault it for that. Try it, I say. Try it!

reviewText:
In theory, Eldritch really should not work. Cthulu has been ruined by the internet, procedural generation and pixelly blocks are things ripped straight from Minecraft, and roguelikes have been said and done time and time again.

Yet Eldritch works, and it works beautifully.

The visuals are obviously not mindblowing, but the simplicity of it all adds to the pick-up-and-play feel of the game, and enemies somehow become generally creepy. Sound design is absolutely superb. There isn't a lot of music but there is a hell of a lot of ambience. Not only do you hear various random noises, but you also can hear the sounds of nearby enemies, which makes you tread the levels of Eldritch ever more carefully.

There are a limited amount of weapons and items, but this allows you to easily adjust your playstyle whenever and makes you master the combat right off the bat so there's no struggle with a learning curve.

There are 3 levels that are entirely different from eachother (and also procedurally generated so they will never be the same) and if you beat these levels in one life, you get a bonus 4th level (which I have yet to play). There is also a free expansion included, with a different snow-themed level.

It's difficult, it's creepy, it's everything that I shouldn't like, and yet Eldritch finds a way to keep pulling me back in again and again.

reviewText: For the truth, I want to recommend this game, but sadly in it's current form it's not much of a whole game.\n\nIt will be interesting, sure but it has for me very little content. This wins some points for being uniquely minimalist and for random levels, spooky atmosphere, and the great framerate. But this also means that there are a great deal of meaningless rooms, freaky but not challenging enemies, and minimalist graphics. If the developer had made the hands less ridiculous looking and gave the game a difficulty setting where enemies would be faster and such, then the game would really pack a greater punch. It's worth getting on sale though.

reviewText:
Im not well known for my ability to write reviews, so i will make this as short and as readable as possible.

-Description- Eldritch is a game about how you got yourself stuck in this dungeon-library type room and need three keys to exit. The way you get these keys are by reading three glowing books in the main part of the room, once you read one of these books (you have to start with one specific book then continue to harder books) it drops you streight into a dungeon, this is where the main part of the game begins. from here on you have to scavange  the place for weapons such as knifes, pistols, even trip wires. and with these you will be able to, obviously, kill the enemys. as you will find out, no-one will beat this on their first try its just way too hard, you will need to learn how to mix stealth AND combat to be able to beat it. this is all im going to say about its description as i do not want to spoil anything (else)

Now i will say the pros and cons to the game as un-biasly as possible.

-Pros-
+The game is easy to run - this is a big one, who likes a game thats laggy? i dont, thats for sure. and this is especially good if you have a simple laptop like mine which cant handly the power savvy games of today.
+The game is aesthetically pleasing -  the game looks nice, pixel games are pixel games but the way  this game puts them toghether with all of its shapes and colors just seems 'right'
+The game is fairly unique - i havnt seen a game much like this before and definatly not one with the same mechanics.
+The game has a sweet and sour feeling - when i first started the game, it scared me...alot just enough to make me lose out of not useing critical thinking. but before the game could lose its fun factor out of being 'scary' i had gotten used to it and was able to play it normally, allowing for a different type of play giving strategy a whole new meaning.
+They are STILL adding more updates - name says it all

-Cons-
= It does eventually get Extreemly hard - this happens around the third and last book, enemys will kill you either one or two shot and it becomes very difficult to play. some will find this as a pro but to me, it could be just a tad easier.

-END-
Thanks for reading and i really hope this helped your decision on wether to but the game or not, would i recommend it? YES this game is unique in many ways and is a must play. if i find any more necessessary pros or cons, i will add  them but for now the only bad thing i can say about it is listed. Wow i made this alot longer than i planned on making it, anyways, goodbye ^u^

9/10 - Great game

reviewText:
Eldritch is a great game


Gameplay is tough, but fun: initially pretty hard (and terrifying), but becomes easier once you're familiar with the enemies and level layouts. Plays a little like a 3D version of Derek Yu's Spelunky, but that's a poor comparison. Involves a nice blend of action with stealth (required on the later levels). Roguelike elements - level generation, item placement etc. makes each run feel fresh. Graphics are really nice, particularly the enemy models, and the atmospheric music and sounds are perfect.
Whilst the main levels are pretty short, it'll take you some time to actually finish them. The new game+ mode is challenging even for veterans. The two bonus" levels offer a great amount of additional playtime: a super-long level and a challenge level
date: that you will be playing again and again to get that 500 souls achievement. The inspiration from lovecraft is a nice touch
recommended: especially since I'm a fan of his works (although the relationship to his original literature is pretty weak).\n\nOverall: Excellent game
hoursPlayed: fun with a lot of replayability.\n\nAlso contains achievements that are damn near impossible. I'LL 100% IT ONE DAY

reviewText:
Being a Lovecraft fan, this game catched my eye a few times and I finally decided to grab it when it was on sale.

It turned out to be a great decision.

Elditch is a game that could be the example of 'roguelike' genre in game encyclopedias. It shows that permadeath is not the only issue for being a roguelike. In this game, there is a chance that you will suffer a horrible death while equipping a pickaxe and a revolver (best equipment combination in my opinion), while at the same time you can finish the game with a single piece of rock.

With the RNG factor, game gives you ultimate freedom for designing your build. You don't start with selecting a class, you choose your own class with your tactics. You can avoid enemies with being silent and invisible, you can kill everyone on your way with a load of bullets and weapons,  you can even be Sanic with proper boots and equipment and run to the exit while ignoring everything.

Atmosphere is simply brilliant. Difficulty is well-balanced and sountrack just fits the dark atmosphere.
Like the enemies weren't already tough, with their noises, you always feel their breath on your back. Better than any thriller. You will sh*t bricks with enemies jumping from corners, especially with a headphone. I also have to mention the invulnerable enemies. Especially Lizard Statues makes you believe in god and beg for mercy from him.
Floors are really well-designed. Traps can possibly be anywhere on a floor and in some cases, you have to be really careful in order to dodge them. So you know, you can always run from scary enemies but you can't escape.

If saying those haven't made it obvious, replayability value is really high. If you somehow become able to steal multiple items from the shops without a scratch, congratulations, you have won the game.

The only flaw I could think of would be the limited item pool, but considering that current items provide you basically everything you could do within the game mechanics, it is not a big issue.


Overall, this game is right in every possible way. A true gem. Can't recommend it enough.

reviewText:
Eldritch somehow reminded me Montezuma's Return. In fact, Eldritch is unique old-fashioned thriller game with good gameplay. Game itself is hardcore, that means if you will die and can't revive yourself with Medical Kit, you have to start over again with different level layouts.

Summarized pros and cons:
+ Old-style distorted graphics (as in PSX games)
+ Story is decent
+ Simple but well made inventory/item system
+ Randomly generated levels
+ As i know, it has multiple endings.

- Actually it has replayability (New Game+, Asylum and unique levels) but in the end, game itself doesn't make you feel like you have to play it again.
- Even though it has a level generator, time by time some patterns are pretty same.
- Stealth isn't a good option in this game.

reviewText:
Wow. This games simple appearance doesn't accurately express it's charm and atmosphere. This game is immersive beyond most modern titles, the sounds and the sound track for each level are diverse and unsettling in every sense.
You might feel that the game is easy off the bat, and in some ways, the game is easy - it's not the difficulty of the enemies that provides all of the challenge here.
But the game falls back on players making the errors, in some ways, klling themselves due to lax in mindset, or not paying attention and falling prey to the games many traps. The environment is what is deadly,  and when coupled with the certain abilities of the enemies.. even more so.

Risk/Reward is built in to almost every aspect. As the currency in the game, Artifacts- is the same thing that you use to cast spells. Making every action when low on health and artifacts incredibly on edge, and can lead to a very intense playthrough where pressing escape to take a breath is a advocated practice.

I've not managed to beat the game, but I've gotten pretty far.
The game offers 3 diverse, Lovecraftian based worlds, with enemies correlating to the particular demi-god of that world. A hub world, which is very cool- and 1 special world in which I've not managed to beat.
All of which are procedurally(randomlly??) generated, which makes the levels seem very maze like, yet fresh and exciting- with twist and turns, ups and downs that can leave you feeling lost and desperate.
Be careful though, 1 mistake and death can cost you your entire run. Caution is of the upmost importance.

The lore of this game is sparse, but told in a simple straightforward way that works with your imagination, over blasting you with cinematics, or long explanations.

It's worth mentioning, that I've delved into lovecraftian fiction works almost exclusively because of this game, just to learn more of the names of these gods, and to try and figure out these odd creatures I'm encountering.
I've left out a lot of things from my words here.. because they are worth finding out for yourself.

Don't skip out on this unique experience, for it's current price, and even full price. It's worth it.

reviewText:
The graphics are minimalistic but the art and design actually make it work. The Lovecraftian inspiration is turned a bit cute and comical, but the art and some scary opponents are surprisingly effective and feel a bit creepy and uneasy at times to times. Especially with the great sound design, reminding of Doom with the weird sounds of the monsters that are lurking around.

First person view is very very suitable to this exploration of randomly generated dungeons. The fighting feels good despite being a bit easy, but some opponents (especially in the second world) are so dangerous that the player experiences a genuine fear to be trapped by them.

Despite the very good variety in opponents, the gameplay feels a bit repetitive after a death when the player has to try again from the start. Replayability is kind of the biggest problem I have with the game. At least some items allow to resurrect (at a cost). I think I would have preferred if the Dungeons/Worlds did not have to be all completed in one life, but instead were independent and harder to complete.


So to sum up, I really liked the Lovecraftian theme, the exploration, and the dangerous and original opponents that sometimes made me feel as if I was in an Amnesia game. I didn't exactly like the way progress is registered. Overall, I was very surprised to actually have a very good time in this game despite its minimalistic looks.

reviewText:
Eldritch is one of the finest examples I have seen of a game that has both simplicity and complexity harnessed in exactly the right measures. The result is a game that is both infintely enjoyable and completely understandable, which is a real rarity. When you couple that with the incredibly well-executed theme, and the sheer polished feel to the whole thing, Eldritch has earned itself a slot on my shelf of all-time-favorites.

The concept is simple: get to the bottom, stay alive, retrieve the thing. But along the way, so many things can go so horribly, horribly wrong that the sense of satisfaction when you finally put your hand on your goal(s) is profound. Each world playes by its own rules and demands different approaches, while everything is at the same time built upon a consistent, understandable basis. Amazing. This is rogue-like done extraordinarily well.

And, it's got Shoggoths. What's not to love.

reviewText:
This game is a lot of fun.  It's a rogue-like game with procedurally generated levels and fully destructible environments, and it pulls this combination off very well.  You can blast holes through walls, sneak around and explore, and defend yourself against enemies very well in the environments it produces.  I feel like I've mastered the base game, but the NewGame+ mode and Mountains of Madness expansion still beat me senseless, and I'm loving the challenge.

I really enjoyed the stealth aspect, and combat is simple but very fluid.  You can sneak behind an enemy, peek around the corner, leap out and stab the unlucky fishman.  Now rush to the next place of safety while his buddy furiously attacks.  Fun times.  :D  This game avoids the regular trappings of holding a button to hug a wall or other gimmicky stealth methods -- it's very approachable, and remains effective as you master it.  I never felt like the controls were inhibiting my ability to sneak or fight effectively.

There's a variety of strategies, including sneaking, sprinting, keeping to high ground, and so on.  Your limited item set increases the challenge, yet still gives you a wide variety of tools and options.  Do I want a destruction amulet to burrow through walls, or a compass to find my way?  Which spell do I want most -- conjure blocks or cloaking?  Do I need the medkit, or tinning kit?

This is not so much an ooga-booga-booga" scary game
date: but it can build to a very tense and even creepy atmosphere
recommended: particularly after you complete the first book.  It ranges from being funny
hoursPlayed: to tense
helpfulPercent: and even freaky.\n\nI recommend it to fans of stealth and rogue-likes in particular."

reviewText:
A fun rogue-like stealth title you can pick up and play for a few minutes at a time (game saves on exit), or be drawn in for significant periods of time - even if you initially intended to play just for a bit. The enemies may look all cute and cuddly but don't be fooled: after the first temple you're up against some mean SOB's and you have to either get good at dodging or really make use of your stealth skills. The difference in difficulty actually works in the game's favour for me; I can use the first temple to go and stab a few fish men when I want to just refresh in the middle of the day and get an actual challenge from the later levels.

In addition to stabbing, shooting enemies you will get to make use of the powers of the Elder Gods, like hypnosis, and there will even be special weapons up ahead after the first temple. I won't spoil them for you, however. The strength of the game isn't in the gadgets though, but in the nicely polished gameplay that balances between sneaking, paying attention to your environment, looting and making a run for it when you find yourself in a sticky situation.

If you enjoy stealth and want a title you can pick-and-play whenever you wish Eldritch is well worth the full 12€ price, and if it's on sale it's an absolute steal!

reviewText: Are you into lovecraftian horror and roguelikes? Ever wanted a three dimensional tough as nails dungeon crawler with a creepy atmosphere and loads of creativity? Then this is the game for you! Add another game to the pile of amazing roguelikes that you'll sink hours into. The game's goal is simple: Find the souls of three great old ones, which are god-like figures of complete insanity, and use them to open a portal through a library while dodging the shoggoths and elder ones that plan your destruction. This game is not for the feint of heart, for just like the HP Lovecraft novels, the alien creatures and strange noises will send a chill through your spine, which is unexpected for such a blocky game. You have two weapon slots, a spell slot which can be filled by praying to eldritch statues of horrible ancient deities, and three equipment slots each with it's own item type: Kits, Amulets and Boots. There are currently 7 worlds to venture through, but you'll be going through the labyrinth-like halls over and over again both from Eldritch's roguelike nature and how replayable it is. And don't even get on the Asylum. If that isn't enough for you, the game is being updated as we speek, the most recent expansion being the Mountains of Madness.\n\nThe game is a love letter to both fans of HP Lovecraft and roguelike players everywhere. Worth the higher price tag.

reviewText:
I really liked the atmosphere, but the games just to simple for me and lacked any depth.
Played for a few hours to get the hang of it, then beat the game start to finish in little over an hour. You're never really rewarded, the combat doesn't require much skill, there are no bosses and theres very little variaty amongst weapons and items.

There are a total of 6 dungeons, 3 you have to collect orbs from to access the final dungeon. The only reward for completing the game is an orb to make the game more difficult.
You mostly wander around looking for a hole to jump through to access the next floor on every floor until you collect the orb, then return to the library hub, start the next dungeon and repeat. The dagger and revolver are the only weapons you'll be using as the other few are not worth picking up.

Guess it's okay if you get it on sale. Really wish it had more content to give it some diversity and it would of been exciting to fight a unique boss at the end of each dungeon. Don't really feel like there are any items in it that change the play style unfortunately, which inhibits replay imo.

reviewText:
Another Rogue-Thing... [KAMGUSTA's REVIEW]

A random-generated minecraft/roguelike game in a horror-fantasy world? Wow it sounds awesome!
It isn't. I was bored after only 30 minutes of play: all you have to do is enter a level, find a key, kill one or more mobs, find the exit and repeat. I didn't find a story either.

Graphic is blocky but nice. Controls are responsive... levels are random generated so you will always find something different... but these are all the positive points I can think about.

Maybe somebody will like this one more than I did. In fact, I don't really understand all those good reviews. Did we play the same game?!

Best played with Keyboard and Mouse
Recommended Buy Price < 5$
Score 6/10

reviewText:
EDIT: Going back through my older reviews, I was a bit dissapointed in my past self for giving such a short and poorly explained review. Brevity does not equal quality, especially when the majority of your original review becomes your final paragraph on re-edit.

Eldritch is a tense, dark, and interesting little game with a lot going for it. As one who grew up with Lovecraft's influences all around me, this seemed to be a dream come true. The added bonus of rogue elements cemented it as something I would love.

As a staunch lover of Isaac and Teleglitch, I'm used to losing everythng. That fear of a run gone sour is always fresh in the back of my head, but that's often the motivation to jump back in for one more go. At the death of my first character, and the loss of every single key item needed to advance the story, I lost interest almost immediately after jumping in again and stopped not long after. Where did Eldritch go wrong?

On a big scale, Eldritch couldn't be better for the gaming market. A voxelized rogue-like with horror elements and a semi-retro artstyle is basically a fusion of everything popular in the indie scene, and they still manage to make the look all their own.

Where the problems emerge is from the very hook; roguelike elements. The gameplay is simple and a bit charming and silly to boot, yet with no stats or leveling, there is nothing for you to improve over time. Of the two weapons in the base game outside of your fists are a knife and a revolver. No more, no less. No upgrades, nor perks. To counter this, there are about 6 magic spells to use with their advantages and disadvantages. Some are useless, while others completely broken in their power. There is some equipment that you can find or buy too, but only a few are worth picking up, but there being about 10 in total makes it easy to find what you want quickly. Money, bullets and keys are your collectables. You can throw rocks and bottles. That's it. Randomization can't change much when you're going to see the same things regardless.

This, sadly, also applies to areas as well. Everything looks the same, and always ends up more or less in the same spot. Different geometry, yes, but once you see it once, you've seen it all. The enemy A.I. is overall mindless as well. Save for the Weeping Angel-esque statues which may make you ♥♥♥♥ yourself first time through, everything follows a simple routine of chase you til you're either too far away or dead. The minecraft elements are fun but make it much easier to circumnavigate trap rooms and such. Once you understand the core game, the threat is minimal, and the game grows dull.

This would be easily forgivable if death didn't obliterate your progress, demanding you do the exact same things in nearly the exact same areas with nearly the exact same challenges, destroying any willpower I had to see it through. Apparently, the ending is a dissapointing text message, so I'm pretty sure I didn't miss much.

Eldritch suffers from an identity crisis. The areas are wonderfully fun the first time through, but there is very little to offer on multiple playthroughs. Whereas Isaac had a wealth of items and combinations to urge you on, and teleglitch entire world shifts with each run, Eldritch sits at a very indecisive middle, with too little of each to justify extended play, and the great parts spread so thin and far with padding, it highlights just how short a game this would be if it didn't wipe all your progress. Good for a weekend if you want something different and it's on the cheap, but ultimately not at all worth full price.

reviewText:
A mediocre title from a barren genre.

So, graded on a curve, its great.

Like many of these indie roguelikes, it lacks content something fierce. The main game is complete within the first 2 hours or so, sooner if you get a good early run and find the item that saves you from death... an infinite number of times. The enemies are surprisingly well designed, and some in dumb, crawley, flying, ranged and far-too-powerful-but-can-be-sneaked. The game isnt really scary but oh man, being chased by several flavors of indestructible horrors that chase you to the ends of the earth sure puts you on edge after a while.

The enemies that can be killed can be looted for ammo or keys or money, but choosing not to loot them prevents them from respawning on the level and HOLY BALLS that is a fantastic idea! The mechanic allows a good risk-for-reward mentality to the later levels. The controls are nice and the physics feel good. There are a good range of spells to unlock and destructible terrain is always a pleasure to mess around with, though I never found a hidden room destroying walls even once so it feels like a missed opportinity unless I am incredibly dumb or unlucky to have not found one.

It does have it's problems though, besides it's brevity I mean. The game's graphics are ♥♥♥♥. This is not really a problem to me normally, but after having two friends catching me playing and asking when minecraft was updated to include lizard-people I had to concede that the game didn't even try to distinguish itself. The textures are legitimately indestinguishable from those in minecraft in some areas, which saddens me because drawing a good 25x25 pixel texture is not difficult. Only having two inventory slots is fine and prohibits hoarding of key items, but what I found myself doing at the end of the day is sticking with the gun and dagger for 99% of the game, dropping the dagger for some dynamite whenever I found some, throwing it against a wall, than backtracking for a few seconds to get my dagger back. This worked great for me, but really broke the flow of the experience for me. Powerful monsters can be avoided entirely through sneaking. The sneaking itself was implemented quite well, but if you find the sneak shoes" it makes the game about as hard as Dora the Explorers Big Birthday Adventure. There are rocks and distraction powers in the game
date: but it's all rendered moot since you can just sprint past all threats
recommended: and any enemy with the slightest bit of perceptive ability can be knifed in the face twice and downed without alerting anyone else. Any level that doesnt include the indestructible shoggoth or weeping angel lizard statues can be sprinted through with no risk whatsoever. Maybe I'm just too good
hoursPlayed: who knows... but I felt unchallenged
voteText: so mlg pros stay away.\n\nLast point

votesTotal: the risk involved in agressing the storeowner was high and immediately obvious. There is no risk here.\n\nOverall
votesFunny: I'd have to say that it was fun knifing cthulu-spawn in the face as Disney's Kim Possible. Assuming this game will get further updates to counter it's short lifespan
commentsCount: it's worth a purchase."

This is my first impressions review after ~1hr of playing.

First off at it's current -80% deal it's practically a must have for anyone who's even vaguely thinking of getting the game or those who love the Rogue-Like genre.

So into the game, it looks very nice and feels well made. I enjoy the fact you can only have 2 weapons/items and spell + some other gear. The game also controls very nicely on KB+M (I may try on X360 controller at a later date, but I enjoy it too much on KB+M at the moment).

After around 30min of playing I was thinking the game was perhaps a little easy with being able to kill all the enemies I'd encountered so far in 2-3 hits with a knife or gun, along with finding the enemies themselves a little sparse. But that certainly changed as I got to the 3rd level of the dungeon, with me dying quite quickly after becoming too overconfident in my abilities, this game will bite back in the later levels.

Short review as I haven't played much but so far I'd certainly recommend this game! Perhaps I might hesitate more at the normal RRP, but as it's 80% off currently I highly recommend buying this game!

Eldritch is a first-person adventure game in which you explore Love-Craft inspired dungeons. Eldritch is like mincraft in graphics only. The game provides a fun adventure, and it's constant updates provide extra levels. Althoug hmany would consider this a rogue-like, I would say it's more like a lite-rpgfps. I will recommend this, but don't excpect too much.

I've had my eye on this game for quite a while after seeing a few youtube videos of it, so I finally got around to actually getting it for myself today. When I launched it the first time, it had me read the EULA, and for some unknown reason, I actually read it. These devs are amazing! Instead of trying to combat piracy with an iron fist, they flat-out tell you that they will never use any kind of DRM, but ask that you purchase the game instead of pirating it. The rest of the rules about how you can use it are incredibly lenient as well (for example, you can share it with as many family members and friends as you like)\nSo there's an cool-looking game made by some pretty damn awesome devs! Whats not to love?

If Spelunky, Minecraft, and H.P. Lovecraft decided to raise a child together, the terrifying little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ would look a lot like this.

Oh, and if you happen to make it to the second level, just remember one thing:

Don't blink.

The game is quite easy, but the random element always keeps you on your toes. I simply can't get enough of it. Every time I think I've seen it all, something weird and unexpected happens.

So after a few rounds heabutting the Rogue-like Dungeon Crawler you die and start anew that is standard in the sub-genre I've grown quite fond in my fairly brief exposure (atm of writing this). The gameplay is a simple FPS with blocky voxel base that puts more charm than effect into the game but does well creating the dungeons, target hieghts and so forth. The game to my latter attempts of knowledge heavily emphisizes stealth in slow creep and crawl survival, i.e. stealth kills, extra loot, unbeatable foe evasion, eh whatnot. The variety of tools your given is a little bland and only offers a simple and straight foward mechanic to your stealth, which isnt a bad thing but i do feel it needs a smidgeon more variety but the simplisity is fine as well and keep yours head straight. I love that the game indulges the player in a foreboding feeling through the game from the music to being able to hear the creatures in an adjacent floor to your own, really sets a good..er mildly terrifying dynamic to it. One thing i dont think they did well was inherrently teach you rules. The first dungeon clunkly drops you into your random gen rogue-like dungeon crawl, but offers simple easy to mow down foes and hardly teaches the player stealth is a practical option to running like a ninny and knifing everything in the face, because once you reach dungeon 2 you get a good healthy slap in the face that brute tactics and running are awful ideas.\nIn general i'll say its a fun game and if you appreciate rich story bits, Rogue-Likes, and horror/survival/stealth games this might be up your Lovecraftian alleyway.

I love the concept, you have nothing and you need to escape of a weird dimention. There are different ennemies with different attack patterns. If you play this game, you'll die a lot. Once you die, you start from stratch but keep the unlocked worlds. Your goal is to collect the 3 souls of each worlds. Once you get them, you'll be able to get free. Or will you?

Eldritch is one of those games that strip out all of the fat and leave only interesting and fun interactions. This is pure, organic gameplay from start to finish, and that's why I love this game.

Eldritch randomly generates levels by compositing premade rooms in a 4x4x3 3d matrix. Most rooms have little nooks and crannies to explore, and the effect on gameplay by one environmental set piece is affected by adjacent rooms. What you end up with is a 3d labyrinth that forms an interesting level on every single playthrough. In my opinion, this method of level generation is superior to alternative methods used in Delver or Tower of Guns.

Stealth is simple yet effective and intuitive in Eldritch. You can lean around corners and crouch to lower your profile and avoid making noise. Attacks on unaware enemies deal more damage, and you can augment your stealth with silent boots, the cloack power, or even the teleport power. (A la Dishonored) In later levels and new game plus, you will need to have mastered stealth to survive.

Not every enemy can be defeated in Eldritch. Shoggoths can not be fought; you must run away. (This can cause moments of terror that remind me of Amnesia.) Similarly, you will encounter wraiths which always revive after a couple of seconds and weeping angel"-like lizard statues that can only be killed with dynamite. (Just don't wake the statues.) In addition to that

reviewText: Eldritch is quite a lot of fun, though somewhat simplistic. There are not a huge amount of enemy types and tilesets, nor are there very many items. However, the levels are very well-generated and interesting, the monsters are creepy, and sneaking around the levels is a LOT of fun. Reviews have said over and over that the game is too easy, and I do concur that the actual act of attacking and killing enemies is typically challengeless as long as you remain unseen or strike quickly. In particular, the first book (level) is very easy. This is not always the case however; sneaking around avoiding combat is very important in the 2nd and 3rd books, and is very tense. I died quite a few times trying to complete the second book, but the third book was fairly easy overall. The end was exceptionally anti-climactic. I haven't tried the New Game Plus mode (unlocked after finishing the game, much harder), but I'm definitely going to give it a play-through (I rarely play a game again after finishing it, but I will with Eldritch, which says a lot).\n\nI would definitely recommend this game to fans of stealth games, those that like the retro blocky look, and Lovecraft fans (the Flying Polyps were particularly disturbing). Also, there's a free expansion coming out in a few weeks, we'll see what it adds.

Pretty interesting game. I like how you are immediately thrown into this mysterious world and have to find out what is going on and fight for your life against weird creatures. Dungeons are randomly generated, which adds to the replayability factor. You can use Rocks, Bottles, Daggers, Revolvers and the occasional Explosives to deal with the hordes of enemies you'll find - from fishmen to screeching worms, from floating eyes to Cthulhu himself.\n\nAll in all, great game, although a little short. Recommended! And oh - don't turn your back to the Lizardmen statues. You've been warned.

An FPS adventure which will keep you on your toes.

Difficulty curve grows a bit oddly in the main game, it's an issue which has been taken care of in Mountains of Madness (MoM) -expansion's content. Also, the main game in normal mode is beat quite fast. That being said, 'New Game+' mode is for those who won't be satisfied after their first playthrough.

The main game consists of an usual playthrough and a more story-driven, a tad more difficult one ingrained within the game world. I won't go any further on that, since one will come across it and eventually decide the way they will continue on: rest assured you will find this to be an enjoyable aspect. MoM's progression is more straight-forward on the other hand, it's flavour coming from challenges thrown at the player as ventured forwards.

Another thing worth mentioning is the soundtrack. Not many other games have so brilliant ambient sounds, consisting of droning electric guitar walls, to create such a gloomy atmosphere. If the graphics and gameplay won't bring up Lovecraft, the soundscape of the game will.

reviewText: I'm very far away from being a good player at Eldritch, but still recommend it. It has a minecraft flavour mixed with simple mechanics that are rarely found. The soundtrack is not very good, though. I mean, it seems to fit the game, but in a way that I would rather avoid playing it than getting into it.

Lovecraftian-themed lo-fi voxel-based Roguelike. Wait! Don't run, come back!

Eldritch combines the greatest bits of games like Spelunky - procedural maps, permadeath, rewarding death-experiences - with the flexible approach and manipulation of game systems common to immersive sims, most notably Dishonored.
A great feature is being able to auto-tweet the cause of your recent ridiculous and probably embarassing deaths.

Also unkillable shoggoths.

Just like Crypt of the Necrodancer (fantastic game btw) this game combines two concepts which wouldn't seem to work well together on paper. Those two concepts are stealth and dungeon crawling. Somehow, Eldritch manages to pull this strange combo off excellently, creating a difficult, tense, edge-of-your-seat experience so chalk-full of the Cthulhu Mythos it's practically got a Hound of Tindalos emerging from one of the corners of your monitor. The campaign may be short, but it is challenging enough to stump you for a while and it makes up for the short length with excellent replay value. The only major shortcoming of the game is that death, while not permanent in any way, feels quite defeating after staying alive for a long time, which has caused me to stop playing on more than one occasion, even while streaming. This is not an issue unique to Eldritch: many drawn-out roguelikes also suffer from it, but it is still unfortunate where it pops up. That being sid, the game is extremely enjoyable, and certainly worth your money, especially if you know your lore.

I want to be clear here; I really, REALLY enjoy this game. The atmosphere is great, the art style is interesting, the gameplay is fairly fun and the Lovecraftian source material is just tops. The maps are pretty interesting while changing just enough in their layout to feel different from one another. Weapons are fairly interesting, with the more powerful ax or pickax being much slower than the quicker knife. There's also a sort of tactical choice in the spells and items you can carry.

Do you want to be sneaky? You'll want Stealth boots and melee weapons, as guns will alert enemies nearby to your presence. Want to avoid combat as much as possible and be able to make quick getaways? You'll want to probably be carrying either a bundle of TNT or a Grappling Hook with you so that you can either quickly climb to safety or make your own escape route by blowing a hole in the nearest surface. Maybe you'll want to equip the Teleport or Lift to get away fast over big ledges. There are quite a few options here.

While this game is great fun as a dungeon crawl, I do have a serious problem with one of the mechanics, and that is the fact that you lose literally everything you have accrued save for any money you've put in your bank chest and any new level you opened. This poses a serious problem.

Throughout the time you character remains alive, you gain more hit points by drinking from fountains, can stock up on ammunition for the revolvers, find spells at idol statues, and, most importantly, find the souls of the Old Ones needed to escape the library hub of the game.

However, when your character lives, you lose literally everything they're carrying; any spell you may have, additional hit points are reduced back to the starting 3, all ammunition, any artifacts (money) you have on your person, all of your gear includeing weaponry, AND any Old One souls you may have found and placed on the three altars to escape the library? Yeah, they're back at the end of a now newly randomized zone. There is a way to revive yourself, if you're carrying a First Aid Kit, but that costs 50 artifacts to use. I suppose unless it disappears (I didn't notice if it was still in my inventory after the one time I was able to use it) that 50 Artifacts to not lose everything is a fairly good deal.

I don't usually take issue with punishment via losing precious items. Games such as Minecraft have made me very familiar with this mechanic, but the issue is that in Minecraft you can store items and the enemies are at a constant level of difficulty, while in Eldritch, the enemies are stronger in each new zone.

There is a sneaking mechanic in Eldritch, and if you can find the Stealth Boots and snag them from a merchant (honestly, who would blow all those artifacts?) you can even sprint without enemies hearing a single footstep, but with the randomized terrain and the fact the enemies actually wander the map it's eventually going to be inevitable that you have to square off against something, and if you've just died and are trying to enter the Mountains of Madness, or are fighting a Snakeman with nothing but your bare fists and three hit points, it becomes more or less a necessity to have to slog all the way through the beginning area again, which is now completely re-randomized, and you are forced to re-collect Dagon's soul.

reviewText: At first glance, Eldritch appears to be a cheap minecraft clone, but what you actually get is a much more fufilling experience. It's a rather charming little game that doesn't try to be anything that it isn't, but at the same time it is also a very intriguing adventure through several levels and labyrinths that become more challenging (or less, depending on the power-ups you find) as you progress through the game. It is not a long game by any means, nor is it too complex, but what it lacks in complexity it makes up for with it's sheer curiousity; You have absolutely no idea what to expect from this game. In short, this game was very pleasant to play through and I definitely recommend this little gem.

reviewText: This game is Fantastic! It's a randomly generated dungeon crawler with some really cool things going for it. Every fight you get in is terrifying, due to your low health and Weapon mechanics (stronger the weapon, harder to find ammo it is). GET IT NOW. Only thing that could make it better would be coop play. *Crosses Fingers*

reviewText:
Eldritch is a First-Person Roguelike, a sub-genre that seems to be growing rather large and unwieldy at times when people want to call it a Roguelike-like or Roguelite, based on the short stories and novellas of H.P. Lovecraft and as you might can guess such an idea very well sounds like a wet dream for many horror readers, myself included.

Luckily it works out, Eldritch is a very well executed and fun Roguelike-like-lite-whatever that blends in elements from procedurally generated worlds to mix well with the horrific atmosphere one tends to expect when it comes to Lovecraft. You start in a library that you are stuck in and three mystic books that transport you to other worlds, Dagon, Nyarlathotep, and R'lyeh, your objective is to reach the end of each world to get the three souls needed to unlock the door and escape from the library.

Much like other Roguelikes you start with low hitpoints, little to no equipment, and when you die you lose everything except for any money you deposit into the bank, with your one life you must gather money, keys, ammo, and equipment, and find fountains to add more hitpoints or statues to give you magic powers, all the while dodging Fishmen, Cultist, Shoggoths, and other eldritch horrors.

The controls and gameplay are very well done, combat is done with relative ease, you can stealth past enemies or sneak attack them, knives for up close attack, rocks to throw, bottles to smash onto walls to lure enemies away, guns can be found though with scarce ammo and sometimes you can find dynamite that will let you blow open parts of the level, most of these items as well as keys to open locked doors can be found in the world, but some can also be bought for money by finding a shopkeeper, this also goes for equipment such as Jump Boots and Good Luck Charms.

Most of the story is told through books you find laying around, and overall despite the great atmosphere, the plot lacks quite a bit and the endings are nothing to write home about, but in the grand scheme of things it is a minor complaint to an amazing game.

Overall this game is well worth playing, though a bit lacking in content, for the price and fun you will have playing it and exploring the very Lovecraftian world it builds, I fully recommend buying this game.

reviewText:
If you like cute games, I heartily recommend Eldritch.  It's a Lovecraftian first person sneaker/roguelike with Minecraft aesthetic.  The shoggoths are particularly kawaii.  Fans of Thief will be immediately at home as this game has Q/E leaning and edge mantling with the addition of sprint sliding!  There's no gaining levels or choosing a class or skills or anything - except finding a few weapons, equipment, keys, spells, health-up fountains and currency(artifacts).  The latter is the only thing that can be saved post permadeath in chests.  Best of luck giving those Elder Things the laugh.

tl;dr version:

Iä! Iä! Cthulhu Fhtagn! Ph'nglui Mglw'nafh Cthulhu R'lyeh wgah'nagl fhtagn.

reviewText:
I picked this up on the Halowe'en sale and can't say I recommend it.
It has a strange ambiance to it that doesn't really feel of anything. Navigation is stressful, the graphics are ugly (and that's from someone who appreciates the charm of Minecraft's visual style), and combat is uninteresting. You can only carry two items at a time, which ends up just making me attached to rare things like dynamite, hoping to find a use for it.
The game's only saving grace is the possibility that if I had played it more, I would have gotten into it - but I doubt it.

I recommend this to people who like Lovecraftian-themed games, and don't mind the weirdly oversimplistic gameplay.
It's hard to explain why - but this game just isn't my cup of tea.

reviewText:
When I first saw this on Steam Greenlight, I was both interested and skeptical. Interested because of the concept, and skeptical because it looked kinda meh. When it did have a Steam release, I decided to wait until it was on sale, and boy was it a mistake.

Let me get the only good thing out of the way first. Eldritch has a wonderful concept. An FPS with rogue-like elements mixed in with some Lovecraftian lore sounds like a great idea. Scratch that, it IS a great idea. But sadly, as mentioned before, this is the only standout feature of the game, as the rest of the game is pure mediocrity. I would like to start off with the gameplay. You start off in a library, which is a base of operations of sorts. Here, you can take out or put in currency that you have obtained throughout the game, enter into levels (of which there are only three, plus that one level introduced in the free expansion pack), and cuztomize the look of your character (you can actually make yout character look like the god of rock and roll frontmen, Freddie Mercury, but this doesn't change the fact that the gameplay sucks). After you enter the level you wish to enter, you are put in a randomly made dungeon, and that is where the ♥♥♥♥ hits the fan. The game is so stupidly easy, and it feels like the game was designed for kiddies who have never played an FPS, as you can only wield two weapons at once, and you can only have one magic spell at a time. The AI isn't any better, as it is dumb as bricks. Currency in the game is used for two things, and that is to buy ♥♥♥♥ and to use magic spells, which is sadly the only other standout feature found in this game. The rogue elements are minimal. In fact, the only rogue part about the game are the randomized levels. Everything else is just look for the items and drink at wells to increase your HP. The FPS gameplay in the end feels generic and lame as ♥♥♥♥, and the rogue elements do not help to stir things up.

Graphically, the game looks like ♥♥♥♥, as it wants to look like an NES game, following that one ♥♥♥♥♥♥ trend in indie games that needs to ♥♥♥♥ing die. Now, you would think that because its graphics are ♥♥♥♥, the framerate would be fine. Instead, you have some very noticable lag in windowed mode, and it is even more noticable in fullscreen mode. This shows that the game is poorly coded and has optimization issues. Overall, not worth your money. You would probably have more fun playing a full rogue-like game.
voteText: 14 of 27 people (52%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A rogue-like game inspired by H.P. Lovecraft's work, what's not to like?

Well, a lot, unfortunately.

Of course, I'm not talking about the graphics... voxel-based worlds kind of grew on me after being forced to play Minecraft and Pixel Gun for countless hours with my son ;-)
The problem is really about gameplay. I tried playing it like a stealth-based game, but it wasn't really that fun. Then I tried playing it Doom style, fully knowing that on a H.P. Lovecraft universe that can only end in tears... and so it did.

So I'm left with a game that feels like a first-person Pac Man game, in which I'm thrown at little mazes, and am constantly trying to eat/grab little rewards while either attacking or fleeing baddies.

Guess what, I'd rather play a real Pac Man game.

And you know what, I was thinking I don't really like humorous takes on H.P. Lovecraft's mythos after all. Cthulhu Saves the Earth" also fell flat for me recently. At least Eldritch made me confirm that feeling."

reviewText:
Eldritch is about as much horror game as a horror-wuss like me can handle. It's basically Minecraft Cthulhu, a first-person dungeon crawler with blocky cartoony environments and monsters. The creepy evil of the Lovecraft mythos does come through, and there is definitely a survival element to the game.

Your investigator character is not a superman. He/she is a normal person, with fairly limited health and ammunition. The monsters are not too bright, but they are legion, immortal and relentless. Should you slowly progress through a level, risking injury, death and getting trapped in order to stock up on more items? Should you race past the dangerous elite monsters, and risk facing a major baddie or trap later, under-leveled and empty-handed?

The audio design, while initially cheesy (most of the monsters sound like the developer's buddy growling into a microphone), is quite effective at instilling a sense of danger. You will find yourself using your ears to judge where a monster is, how far away it is, and what it is. And you will have to make tough choices with that knowledge.

As a newbie to the genre, I recommend this as a fun horror-lite first-person dungeon crawler. I suppose if you like concentrated terror and wearing brown pants, you could go play Amnesia or Alien: Isolation. But this is about as much creepiness as my britches can handle for now.

One paranoid investigator's thumb up!

reviewText:
A clever and minimalistic lovecraftian themed stealth rougelike that does exactly that and excells at it.
Although jarring at first, the minecraftian feel to the world combined with a very well polished combat and physics system, allows players to slip n slide n slice n shoot their way though horrorifyingly cute monsters. The whole game just does it well, so well, and any hesitation I had twards writting this off as just another minecraft clone was shattered, as this is nothing of the sort and FAR more. A great game, and the holloween update adds a fun and intresting challange area that really helps bring this game into the light, as shadowy and dark as it might be.

I'd love to see this ported to Android, As this would probably consume even more of my attention on the go.
9/10, would buy again.

reviewText: A rogue-like FPS inspired by the ouvre of H.P. Lovecraft, Eldritch is fun. It can be creepy, difficult, fast and furious - but overall, it's fun. The Minecraft-esque graphics are in no way an indication of gameplay, which can get quite intense, down in the dungeons with all those eldritch horrors (don't get me started on the stone lizards ...). The soundtrack's a little sparse (unlike the trailer), but it all adds up to a wonderful creepy feeling, where you're not sure if you should giggle or shriek. Definitely worth your time, especially if you're a fan or rogue-likes and/or Cthulhu.
