reviewText:
So imagine Minecraft as a randomly-generated dungeon crawler like Nethack, pitting you against the shambling horrors of the Cthulhu Mythos. That's pretty much Eldritch right there - and holy crap, is it fun. I may have to uninstall it until my class projects are done. (No prior knowledge of the Mythos is necessary!)

Runs cleanly and fluidly even on lower-spec hardware, thought I'd have to draw the line on trying to play this on an Atom-CPU-powered netbook for example. Plays very smoothly on an i5 notebook with Intel's GPU.

Anxious for Linux support and better STEAM integration (including cloud saves, achievements, and trading cards).

Highly recommend!

reviewText:
Aesthetically the game owes a lot to Minecraft, which is reasonable when you consider you can blow apart walls/floors or create new ones with spells.  It didn't add anything to the game, but it didn't detract as much as I was worried it might.  The enemy models were still entertaining (I loved the fish people and the cthonians).  The sound design was well done, keeping things extremely tense, but still being necessary to know when someone was walking up behind you.

Gameplay-wise, it was somewhere in between true rogue-like and the kind of game I prefer where most of your advancement carries over between attempts.  Unlocked levels and artifacts carry over (or CAN carry over, in the case of artifacts, provided you found a chest to store them in before you die), though trying to jump into the later unlocked levels without the advancement from the earlier levels is foolish at best, so I found it better to just restart at the beginning anyway.

One thing I found interesting was that the strategy that ended up working for me was finding a shop in the first area that had a health pack (the only way in the game to get continues") and
date: instead of trying to save up your artifacts to purchase it (since you'll need them to buy continues) just save up bullets until you have a dozen or so and kill the shopkeeper.  Then you can loot the health pack
hoursPlayed: and a pair of boots which will keep you going for the rest of the game.\n\nThe game isn't long
voteText: though I haven't played through the Mountains of Madness DLC.   There is a spell system in the game that I never even bothered with
helpfulPercent: since that spends artifacts and I was hoarding them for continues
votesHelpful: though I do like that you get spells by praying to different elder gods.\n\nAll in all it was an entertaining
votesTotal: tense
votesFunny: dungeon-crawly rogue-like with just a sprinkle of Lovecraft mythos on top.  No buyers remorse here."

reviewText:
Eldritch is about as much horror game as a horror-wuss like me can handle. It's basically Minecraft Cthulhu, a first-person dungeon crawler with blocky cartoony environments and monsters. The creepy evil of the Lovecraft mythos does come through, and there is definitely a survival element to the game.

Your investigator character is not a superman. He/she is a normal person, with fairly limited health and ammunition. The monsters are not too bright, but they are legion, immortal and relentless. Should you slowly progress through a level, risking injury, death and getting trapped in order to stock up on more items? Should you race past the dangerous elite monsters, and risk facing a major baddie or trap later, under-leveled and empty-handed?

The audio design, while initially cheesy (most of the monsters sound like the developer's buddy growling into a microphone), is quite effective at instilling a sense of danger. You will find yourself using your ears to judge where a monster is, how far away it is, and what it is. And you will have to make tough choices with that knowledge.

As a newbie to the genre, I recommend this as a fun horror-lite first-person dungeon crawler. I suppose if you like concentrated terror and wearing brown pants, you could go play Amnesia or Alien: Isolation. But this is about as much creepiness as my britches can handle for now.

One paranoid investigator's thumb up!

reviewText:
Eldritch is an indie, stealth game that has you make your way through a trio of randomly generated dungeons in order to collect three orbs and escape the library. The fun comes from the fact that, if you die, you lose all your orbs, your equipment, and your status is completely reset, meaning that in order for you to escape, you need to beat the entire game in one life.

It's quite an interesting catch, and it truly embodies the gameplay aspect of learning and mastering the game's mechanics. Games like Assassin's Creed and other mainstream triple-A games treat their players like idiots, constantly reminding them of how to play the game and perform basic techniques at every stage of the game. Not Eldritch. Eldritch barely gives you a tutorial, and by the end, you feel like you've truly mastered the game. There are a lot of unique enemies, such as enemies that can't die, that come back to life after a few seconds, and even a not-ripoff of the Weeping Angels from Doctor Who, that, if you stop looking at them, attack you. It keeps you on your toes and makes it so that every enemy type is a learning experience. How many hits do these enemies take? Can they hear my footsteps from far away? Do they have any projectile attacks? Is it worth fighting them or running?

The game isn't that long. It takes about twenty to thirty minutes to beat a dungeon, and there are optional bonus dungeons that can break up the monotony, and offer special equipment to better tackle the big three dungeons (such as grappling hooks and pickaxes). My final 'life' that I beat the game with only lasted 77 minutes, meaning that, if you're a master from the get-go, you can beat it in an hour. But it took me four hours to beat the game, so it took three hours of failed attempts, learning enemy behaviour, and trying new equipment and tactics, to finally master the game and beat it.

Unlike Rogue Legacy, another one of my favourite perma-death games, nothing transfers over from one life to the next: not health, not equipment, not even the boots you're wearing. Although Rogue Legacy was satisfying to beat, this felt even better, because dying in this game felt punishing, but you constantly felt like you were getting better.

It feels like those old NES games that were only an hour long, but because they're so challenging, it took months or years to beat as a kid. But you took the time (because games were expensive and you wanted to beat the ones you had), mastered the game, and by the end, you could recite every level's floor-plan off by heart. Eldritch is very much in the same vein: a short game that takes a long time to beat. It rewards patience, skill, and willingness to approach a situation from new angles.

For stealth fans, this is a fun game, but for people who enjoy a challenge, there is nothing more rewarding than beating this game.

reviewText:
Eldritch looks like the developer wanted to take the spelunking from Minecraft and slap some Lovecraft on it.
That sounds good enough for me to get the game, but sadly it doesn't live up to the expectations.

The thing is, when you dig down in Minecraft, you don't know whether you're supposed to survive that.
The caves aren't even made to be traversible, you could fall through a hole any time. You could hit lava, water or sand. The enemies aren't made to be killable/survivable with the most basic of equipment.

If you take this out of the sandbox and make it a game on it's own, there's this implicit contract between game developer and player that says: this is doable". This takes all of the tension away. This is something that should be apparent in the prototype stage of a game's production.

Eldritch has easily traversible rooms which are "clean"
date: compared to the messy world of MC.\n\nYou can run so fast
recommended: that you don't even need to engage a single enemy. You can just run past to the exit (especially easy if you have a compass).\n\nThere are so few items in the game
hoursPlayed: that I kept finding the same dagger and pistol over and over again.\nThe dagger swings very rapidly and stunlocks enemies
voteText: so that there's really no need for other weapons.\nMost enemies die to a single hit. You can even throw the empty revolver at them and they keel over."

reviewText:
So let me start off with a pros & cons list...

-----PROS-----
-Randomly generated worlds
-Sneak mechanics in a randomly generated world is a nice twist
-Surprisingly spooky & ambient

-----CONS-----
-Poor graphics that don't seem thematic, but lazy.
-Very short, and with little replay value. (You can see that I've only played for 3.1 hours, more than enough time to beat the main campaign with absolutely no previous experience)
-Enemies are all very, very similar. There seems to be about two different AI types, excluding the rock lizards and the slug thing. They pretty much either fly around or walk at you, and sometimes they shoot energy blasts.


I got this game during a Humble Bundle, and was glad I didn't pay full price for it.  While I've oftentimes seen this game compared to spelunky, making that comparison is similar to comparing Minecraft and Terraria. Yes, there's mining and building and exploring, but that's about as far as you can draw the comparison. The biggest, most notable difference between Eldritch and Spelunky is the fact that this game is a roguelite, not a roguelike, like this game seems to advertise. Once you complete a world, the next area is permanently unlocked, with zero reason to visit earlier levels. You can also store the games currency at different parts of the level, to be withdrawn at a later time, or a later life.

Another big complaint I have about this game is the fact that the graphics do not play to their strengths, much like many other indie games do. These graphics feel lazy, and oftentimes just make the game feel less professional. Yes, it's an indie game, but must indie games when confronted with graphic issues take a simple, more retro style and play to the strengths of that particular style.

While the gameplay is solid, I don't feel like replaying the game. I don't feel like it has anything more to offer me than what I had experienced on my first playthrough. The game offers a New Game+ feature for those who beat it, but it feels slapped on, as if they just altered a few numbers in the code and called it good.

This game is alright, but I don't reccomend it. If I still haven't swayed you, the only advice I can give to you is don't buy this game for anything over 50% of the full cost.

reviewText: If there's a rogue-like you have to buy, it's Eldritch. Based off the writings of H.P. Lovecraft, this game combines cute and creepy in the perfect manner. You have a variety of worlds to unlock and explore, with a very simplistic HUD and inventory system. That makes it easy to get into the game and start exploring. From throwing rocks to blasting with dynamite to a variety of magic spells to choose from, the player's bound to develop their own unique method of getting through the game. The library is where you start, and from there you can go to the Mountains of Madness, or explore the book-worlds of Dagon, Nyarlthotep, and R'lyeh. Each book-world has shops, traps, evil denizens, and quirks, all procedurally generated so no two journies are alike. If you wanna see a Cthulhi wearing a monocle or if you wanna punch a penguin to death, I would suggest this game before all others.

reviewText:
Eldritch is a Firstperson roguelike game with a lowres art style, which sort of resembles minecraft. I remember hearing about this game and instantly being interested, so I bought it for 15bux... only to be let down.

For 15bux, this game doesn't really have that many features (especially for a roguelike, which games usually have tons of features and be free as in free beer and freedom) and feels more like a 5 dollar or less game. I guess it is a little fun to do in short bursts, but it's not worth the extremely high price of 15bux, nor would it be worth 10bux... yet some how, this made number 50 on top 50 best fps games ever made, which really makes me question why the hell it would even be on that list, when it's so minimalistic in graphics and features, and there's barely any shooting (literally just one gun, maybe 2 if we're talking projectile weapons that shoot). You're pretty much telling me that every game that isn't mentioned on that RPS list is WORSE than this.

You're better off paying for Vulture

reviewText:
Do not let the low quality graphics confuse you - this game banked it all on a solid UI and well done mechanics.

No instruction manual but for some basic popups - but those popups cover you quite well.

The hotkeys are very natural to what you're used to.
The sounds is true 3D sound, you and other things make noise and the sound is increased/decreased in volume based on your position to every noise source.

Great fun, great fun indeed!

reviewText: If you're a fan of H.P. Lovecraft's mythos, or just enjoy some simple Roguelike exploration, Eldritch is 100% for you.  Four worlds as of the time of this review, each one based upon various stories and beings within the Cthulhu mythos (including the infamous Mountains of Madness), brought to you in a Minecraft-style first person perspective.  Randomly-generated procedural labyrinths, some rudimentary resource management, mystical powers, irritable shopkeepers, dungeon exploration, death traps, invincible Shoggoths...  it's all there, watching.  Waiting.\n\nWelcome to the Library.

reviewText:
I'm on the fence whether to downvote this game or to upvote. I'll post it as an upvote for now, but I'm teetering on the edge, simply because of a few factors that are pretty noticable once you start playing for a while.

The biggest factor being that it's too easy. Yes, sure, there's a new game plus, but the base game was so easy that I'm pretty sure that a new game plus wouldn't be too much harder to be honest.

Another factor to consider is the length of the game. Had I not experimented with different features of this game and always played stealthily taking no chances, it's probably a three hour game at the very least.

Now the good things about this game are that it has a stealth system, strikingly similar to that of Dishonored's. Dishonored was a great game to me; I replayed it many many times. So to have stealth similar to Dishonored's really made me ecstatic.

I also like roguelikes, and this is definitely a roguelike. Although like I said before, it's a pretty easy roguelike, so it's not a true" roguelike
date: if that makes sense.\n\nAll in all
hoursPlayed: but again
helpfulPercent: this game's VERY short and a little on the easy side. Definitely pick it up when it's on a sale."

This game is absolutely terrifying. great mash of lovecraftian themes, dungeon crawling and stealth/fps combat.

Random generated dungeons replacing previous dungeons whenever you die make you think a lot harder about how you play but isnt irritating but actually adds a lot of depth to the game.

reviewText: The most merciful thing in the world, I think, is the inability of the human mind to correlate all its contents. We live on a placid island of ignorance in the midst of black seas of infinity, and it was not meant that we should voyage far. The sciences, each straining in its own direction, have hitherto harmed us little; but some day the piecing together of dissociated knowledge will open up such terrifying vistas of reality, and of our frightful position therein, that we shall either go mad from the revelation or flee from the deadly light into the peace and safety of a new dark age.

reviewText: There are two things about this game does that makes the gameplay better then a lot of AAA games.\n\n1. In most games when you die you go oh no
date:
I have to do that all over again" and eventually "OH PLEASE GOD! NO MORE!"
But this is not an issue in this game because the levels are different each time.

2. The issue in a lot of AAA games these days is that they have these long fancy animations for each action you do in the game. So you can run at an enemy and attack then say "this was a bad idea
recommended:
and try to run, only the person you are controlling is still doing the animation so you can't run and end up getting killed. In this game that is not an issue, as soon as you press the button the action happens, finishes, and is ready for the next action.

The issue I have with the game is that even though the QUALITY is very good the QUANTITY is not. This is because the game was made by only one person… I think (no, I can't be bothered to check). I hope that AAA games can learn something from this game.

reviewText: Passable. Eldritch has some interesting ideas going for it, combining a Spleunky type (descend, collect treasure, dodge traps) premise and fast paced movement with FPS combat and view. It also has an almost useless sneaking system along with various ways to play the game, but very few penalties to run as fast as you can" as long as you're paying attention. In fact if you can beat Eldritch in ten minutes (which is easier than you may think). As you progress you start seeing more invincible/immortal enemies
hoursPlayed: but more often then not you feel like the game's short and bloated with tons of options
voteText: but little reason to pursue them. For example the sneaking system (running makes a lot of noise
helpfulPercent: crouching almost eliminates the noise you make) is best used in the third world against enemies who are sleeping. But if you have the dagger - the first weapon you can find in the game - you can beat any enemy just by running around them and slashing at them. By the end of the game I had over 100 shots for the revolver which I used to eliminate all challenge. Plot's as basic as it gets
votesHelpful: but after you're finished there's a harder NG+ option which I'm not too motivated to pursue. There's also three additional areas they've added with the game since its release: a gauntlet in the form of the Mountains of Madness
votesTotal: an arcadey time trial in the Asylum (my personal favorite
votesFunny: died there a lot more then I did anywhere else)
commentsCount: and a quick run starter in a Halloween level. The variation they give is nice
column16: but more like after dinner desserts that give the game just enough flavor from being a bit dull.\n\nIf the premise interests you (it sure did me) I'd wait for a sale. Sadly it barely surpasses being average but that's enough for a recommendation."

reviewText: Eldtrich is quite a unique game save from Delver. The aim is to explore large dungeons in order to find the means of opening new dungeons. You can gather items to whoops sharp asses, paper asses, jelly asses, invisible asses, and jo mammas ♥♥♥ with. Or you could buy things to do so. Or you could steal things to do so. It's really up to you. And that's awesome. You can hop down into the dungeon, and do whatever you want! Really! There's no tight paths, or railed exploration, you walk around, explore fight, sneak, eat, non-eat, you decide. It's really cool. I have so much fun with it every time I play it. The varied levels and environments are really wowing. Sometimes you're in a library, sometimes you're in a sewer. I once found myself in a bank with several locked doors. I spent a while exploring for keys to unlock each door, because after each door, there was more and more cash! You never know what kind of adventures you have. Please BUY THIS GAME!

reviewText: A rogue-like dungeon crawler with graphics similar to Minecraft. The main objective of the game is to go through 4 different levels with 3 floors on each level, and collect the orbs awaiting you at the end of the dungeon. Once you collect all 3 orbs you can continue on to the last level. Keep in mind you have to do this all in one life, which makes the game somewhat difficult. After you beat the game you can play new game+ or play the challenge dungeon and try to get a high score. 8/10

reviewText:
A fine example of roguelike(lite?) done right. This game has, at first glance, mucky graphics, but do fit well with everything that happens within the actual game. It has dungeon crawler written all over it, and the HP Lovecraft feel/inspiration is enough to grasp fans and unfamiliars alike. The game has solid gameplay, basic controls with very little to learn. It's forgiving at times, and unforgiving the next. It has a very nice simplistic feel to it with a bit of story tacked on, but not in a bad way. If you want it solely because you want a decent roguelike, pick it up. If you like HP Lovecraft, pick it up. If you want a decent mystery/horror game, pick it up.

Overall?: 8/10.

It will keep you gripped for a long while to come, and it's easily addictive. Being the roguelike it cherishes itself to be, it will be able to have some high replayability. There is a bit of a learning curve to overcome, but nothing too threatening.

reviewText:
There is something moving around on the other side of this wall. I can hear it shuffling and dripping some kind of unspeakable ichor as it slides over the ruined stonework. I have only my knife and a rock to keep me safe in this cyclopean hell and I must make it back to the relative safety of the labyrinthine library. A giggle rises from my lips, but I quickly silence myself. I cannot afford to lose my sanity in these deep corridors. I creep forward, darting my view in all directions. Suddenly, there is a dreadful noise behind me! I turn whilst steeling myself against this fresh horror… Awwww! It’s just the sweetest looking Deep One I’ve ever laid my eyes on! Come here, li’l guy! Come – OH GOD, WHY IS IT KILLING ME?

Eldritch, by Minor Key Games, is a first-person roguelike set in a blocky Lovecraftian fantasy. It’s unforgiving of mistakes, and it’s so dang adorable, you’ll want to hug every deadly enemy you see. Next thing you know, you’re looking at the death screen, getting ready to resurrect back in the mysterious library.

Like any good Lovecraftian horror, Eldritch begins with forbidden knowledge. You awaken in a library. Endless shelves of books, tables, and reading lamps surround you. The only exit requires the acquisition of three magical orbs to unlock. Reading one of three glowing books in the middle of the library will transport you to a deadly realm filled with traps and monsters. Your exploration of these three randomly generated dungeons will net you loot, weapons, and the orbs that will free you from imprisonment. Dying puts you back in the library. The catch? You have to gather the orbs in one life. If you die before you unlock the exit, you’ll lose any orbs you have returned to the library, forcing you to gather them again.

The first dungeon you go into is easy. It’s baby’s first roguelike. You’ll be punching cultists, Deep Ones, and beetles to death. You’ll run through the halls with abandon. You’ll be given a magic spell by praying at a statue of Dagon and the artifacts that power your spell will litter the ground. You’ll find a revolver and you’ll never run out of bullets because looting the dead gives more ammo than you spent. The knife is god-tier. You’ll grab the first orb and you’ll teleport back to the library thinking, “This is it?” It’s a trap. In the second dungeon, you’ll run into deadlier monsters that will laugh at your ineffectual flailing. Your gun will never have enough bullets. The hissing Serpent Men will chase you. You’ll begin hoarding the increasingly scarce spell-powering artifacts. You’ll realize that the gameplay resembles Dishonored with its sneaking, spells, and assassinations. Just as you’re getting your groove again, a Shoggoth will crush you with it’s cuddly black tentacles. Awwww. You’ll wake up back in the library.

That’s when the deeper mechanics of Eldritch start to make sense. There’s a lean button for a reason. Crouching makes you stealthier. Looting the enemies you kill makes them respawn somewhere else in the level. A rock can be the best ranged weapon because it’s quiet and you can recover the missile after you’ve thrown it. The knife is best used in sneak attacks from behind or above. Bottles can be thrown as a distraction. The Shoggoth will kill other denizens of the dungeon for you if you lead him into them. Spell-powering artifacts can be banked in a treasure chest so you don’t lose everything when you die. You’ll discover that you can purchase weapons and power-ups from oddball merchants. Do you want to keep your artifacts for spells, or spend them on boots that let you leap higher? You can unlock shortcuts to deeper dungeons, but zipping right to harder levels without getting some better equipment is a mistake. Finally, a Chthonian Worm will bite you to death with its lovable lamprey mouth. Awwww. You’ll wake up in the library again.

The screen that informs you that you’ve died again has a button that lets you tweet the manner of your death to the world. It’s a painful reminder that Eldritch could really benefit from leaderboards or at least achievements to chronicle your struggles against the forces of cosmic terror. It’s hard to play any roguelike without a scoreboard after Spelunky’s wonderful daily challenges. No matter. Unlike Spelunky, most players will see the end before their hundredth death. Onwards! There are cute monsters to kill.

This time, you’ll use the run-and-crouch move to slide through a hole as a Spawn of Chthulhu chases after you. This spell lets you teleport behind that Deep One and stick him in the back before the nearby cultist knows what happened. There’s the orb! If you can only reach it before the moaning horror catches up to you! Nope. You weren’t watching your step and the collapsing floor dropped you right next to your Shoggoth friend. Awwww. Back to the library with you.

Recommended
Be sure to check out Nerd House Gaming for more reviews!

reviewText:
It's a great unique stealth fps with levels like you have never seen before.

Don't buy it for those reasons:
- It's only a light Roguelike, ie the difficulty isn't high, the randomization is just fair, don't buy it for this aspect.
- It uses Lovecraft lore as thematic and there's some parts with a nice mood plus some interesting implementation of some monsters, but don't look for a Lovecraft game.

But you could buy it for those reasons:
- It is very fun from the fps stealth point of view, the stealth gameplay is quite intuitive and feels more natural than usual.
- It has huge large levels with an extreme exploitation of heights as almost no fps made use at this level, one exception I know is the old fps Po'ed. That levels design would be enough to justify the use of sample graphics, to allow such large and complex levels inside descent production cost.
- The levels have a fair randomization, but they have also an accurate tuned design for the exploration and progression point of view.
- It offers a good range of tools to manage the levels in different ways.
- Some monsters are quite unique, without to spoil anything, one really worth the quote, some statues you really need experiment in the game.

Overall it's a game aimed to be relatively short but quite intense. The rogue-like aspect uses the fair randomization and helps increase the duration. It's a light fps stealth game with unique large levels exploiting intensively the heights, some parts succeed generate a rather good mood despite the low budget on graphics and sounds.

reviewText:
Here is why I - DO NOT GET THIS GAME.
Yes, the videos make it look kinda fun and enjoyable. Its not. I was looking for a game that I could start and stop randomly that never got boring like Nuclear Throne. When this game was on sale for a dollar, I got it so I could at least see if it was fun. it wasnt. I got bored in the first 5 minuts. Here's a list why.

Bad
-Only two usefull weapons: the knife and the gun. Everything else is useless, weak or only lasts once.
-Grappling hook does not even work like a grapple. It creates a ladder which is very glitchy.
-Graphics get really annoying
-More boring and extrmely repetitive (more than minecraft story mode)
-Stupid. If you dont know what to do, find dynomite and blow up the dungeon.
-The saggoth is incredibly hard to kill. I used 20 shots from my pistol and it didnt die. Most creatures die from one shot.
-You dont have a body. You can barely see your arms if at all, and you cant see your feet.
-Most monsters are super easy to kill and are really boring.
-You will die everytime from the stupidest thing and get annoyed and bored very quickly.
Good
N/A

reviewText:
The game is extremly easy. For a game that dare have the Rogue-like tag, its a damn shame.
I played the game for 2 to 3 hours, died 4 times (1 was because I went inside the DLC world which is the hardest) and I managed to finish the game
Just by having the stealth boot and a knife, I was litterally set for life. Ammo isn't scarse. I could end up very quickly with 40 ammo, and only run out of it at the near end.
The powers you can get ingame are either useless or overpowered, luckly you can only have one on you at all time
One could make me unlock doors, making the keys useless
The second one was teleport, which was utherly useless
The last one was the Cloaking power, which I never used because I had stealth boot could have made me overpowered if I wanted to, be invisible AND unheard makes you unkillable
For its current price (15 US$) I do not recommend it.
Its boring after the first playthrought, it took me less than 3 hours to finish it and I feel scammed out of my money.

This aint a Rogue-like game...

If you like rogue-likes get this game."

Yes, it looks like something from the 90s, but who cares? It is a well-crafted stealth/action game that introduces new elements at a measured pace. It forces you to make important decisions with your weapons and tools and to improvise  based on what you have on hand.\nFor example, there's a corridor that's lousy with statues that teleport behind you and beat you up when you look away from them. But they have to notice you first. It would've been nice to have the invisibilty spell, but I did have the block-creation spell and something that let me dig. One hole in the wall and careful line-of-sight blocking and I was on to my goal and feeling quite pleased with myself.\n

The first time I played Eldritch, I was significantly turned off by the Minecraft-esque graphics. I didn’t play it again for a good long while, but I did eventually give it a second chance. The graphics, as it turned out, worked with the game and playing through it turned out to be a very good time.

I – Story [5/10]

Eldritch is a roguelike FPS with a kick ♥♥♥ Lovecraft theme and perma-death from the brilliant minds behind Minor Key Games. Story-wise, there’s not a whole lot to it though. You (the character) are trapped in a seemingly endless library filled with strange books that transport you to alien realms. In each realm, you must collect a spherical treasure to unlock the next and, ultimately, escape the library.

II – UI [10/10]

The user interface was as simple as they come. The mini-map in the corner (while a bit confusing initially) becomes vital to navigating the dungeons. It was easy to see what items you currently had in your inventory, stats were clearly displayed, and (after several runs) it wasn’t hard to decipher what spell you were currently wielding.

III – Gameplay [10/10]

Gameplay is where Eldritch truly shines. Anytime a game has sprinting, it’s a good thing. Anytime a game has sliding, it’s a great thing. Anytime a game let’s me punch a shoggoth in the face before promptly being devoured for my foolish mortal bravery, it’s just fantastic.

Eldritch has that “one more run and then I’ll quit” quality that keeps you coming back for more. Every death down in the dungeons (be it from my own carelessness or at the tentacles of horrific monsters) got me just a little bit more hooked. It’s like a slot machine; ultimately frustrating, but impossible to walk away from.

The game itself looks simple, but it’s surprisingly deep. The replay value is very high, not to mention the addictive quality of it. I had no complaints about it as a whole.

IV – Content [5/10]

Much to my chagrin, there was not enough content in Eldritch. Seeing H.P. Lovecraft’s creations brought to life is always a good thing, no matter what kind of graphics you’re dealing with. While there was a good amount of enemies to banish from the mortal realm, there weren’t nearly enough.

Also on this topic, there was a definite lack of items. One solid run in the dungeons can show you practically all the items you’ll be dealing with for the entire game.

V – Visual [7/10]

As much as a appreciate the 8-bit like medium, I deeply wished it had not been so for Eldritch. A graphical re-work of this game could turn it in to a certifiable masterpiece, and, while the graphics do work with the overall feel of the game, it left me very wanting.

VI – Audio [6/10]

There wasn’t much music in Eldritch, but what little music there was was pretty good. I enjoyed and it didn’t detract from the atmosphere in anyway.

The sound effects could have used some more variety however. You can quickly learn what sounds are coming from what monsters and, while this is a great thing to know as far as your survival is concerned, it gradually reduces the overarching tone of danger the longer you play and become more familiar with the game.

VII – Overall [7.2/10]

On the whole, Eldritch is a great game and absolutely worth the price tag. If you can get it on sale, great, even better. If you’re looking for something new or your a fan of Lovecraft, this just may be the game for you.

Eldrich is a 3D, first person, horror RPG inspired by H.P. Lovecraft, the father of cosmic horror. Navigate and survive in a randomly generated Minecraft styled world and fight different monsters, from simple cultists to fishpeople to the unkillable shoggoths. Heck, you may even see Chuthulu (not actually sure if you do) himself! Use differnt weapons to fight said creatures; bottles, rocks, knives, and if your lucky then you may find some TNT.  Be stealthy and and survive or not be stealthy and decreace your chances to survive.\n\nEldrich is a great buy and I would recomend it any day.

Quick review: Well worth the purchase, spend your money on this product.

Longer review: Eldritch is the kind of game a lot of us roguelike fans look for. Each world you enter has 3 levels, each level having 3 layers, which at first doesn't sound like a lot. However each level is made by several randomly generated 'squares' holding random items, enemies and secrets to hunt out. Sometimes the generated parts don't seem to fit in with the squares next to it but considering the lovecraftian theme of the game this really only adds to the bizarre non-euclidean feel to the worlds with each world feeling increasingly dangerous and bizarre.

Now a bad part of this game is that if you push through with a speed run it's not hard to finish, however the real charm to this game is taking your time to explore every nook and cranny of the levels you're in. Finding the little secrets and involving yourself in the survival aspect of the game is really what brings out the charm and tension the game has in spades.

Lovecraft fans  will get a huge kick out of identifying the various monsters you can slay (or more likely run away from) and even get a laugh out of the shopkeepers that are unique to each world (The veiled lady Shoggoth was my personal favourite). Speaking of shopkeepers the game really has a great mechanic in the form of artifacts, which act as both your source of magic and currency. Do you spend the artifacts you have to get some vital upgrades in the shop, or save them for the unholy powers granted by the Cthulhu statues? Or even put them into your bank, to save in case you die later on? Bullets are also somewhat scarce to come by and sooner or later you WILL find yourself falling back on to stealth to sneak past enemies or risk going up behind them and taking them by surprise. Another great mechanic lies in if you want to loot the fallen foes for possible ammo, keys or artifacts but be warned, looted foes WILL rise again to continue hunting you through the levels. More than once you'll find yourself making the tough choices to risk another battle with a monster just to gamble on getting an extra key or much needed revolver ammo.

You could maybe point out the blocky graphics count as a negative but for us born before the year 2000 the graphics only add an old school FPS look to everything, when games would punish you for making mistakes and, trust me, this game will PUNISH YOU for acting cocky or not thinking an action through. Think you're tough because you've got full health and a strong weapon? You'll be cursing blind when something leaps out at you from the shadows and mauls you to death because you weren't checking every corner for fishmen, star-spawn or cultists.

If I was to think of anything truly negative I would say the repetitive enemies and the occasionally simplistic AI can take you out the game, especially when you find the block power or find yourself knifing a Elder Spawn to death by strafing around it. It can be very easy to MAKE the game easy if you know what you're doing and finding the high ground early on is a good way to make things easier (until the flying eyes come at you...).

In all this game is a fantastic buy and very involving, especially from what I understand is a small two-man stuido. I hope they produce more content for Eldritch in the future. Absolutely recommended!
As silly looking as this game is, it's wonderful, I could happily play this game for hours and hours.\nI would happily buy a sequel or DLCs for this game.

Positives about the game:
Fun and varied gameplay
High replay value
Very atmoshpheric with the creepy sounds and lovecraftian inspiration
NOT a minecraft clone despite similar graphics
Not super difficult, a good introduction to the roguelike genre
Hardcore mode for those who want a  challenge

Negatives:
Some might be put off by the minecraft-ish graphics

That's pretty much it, any other grievances probably have more to do with the genre than with the game itself. It's pretty light on story and lore, but that's typical of games of this genre so I can't hold that against it.

Despite the similar graphical styling, the only common factor of Eldritch and Minecraft is the slight sense of dread while exploring unknown areas. I'd recommend it if you're a fan of Spelunky or Dishonored, but it's a must buy if you're a fan of both. Controller support is excellent, though keyboard and mouse work equally well.

The game is short, but it is also sweet.  Being first person adds a lot to the scary factor to the game.  While most times you'll only be worried about dying, the second stage has some very interesting features that make you nervous while you aren't watching your back.\n\nTry to get this game on sale.  It isn't worth $15, but it is certainly worth playing.

I dig this game for many reasons.

1) I love me some H.P. Lovecraft inspired stuffs. This game definitely feels like one of his great stories.
2) Sure, the graphics are kinda crappy, but that is kinda one of the charms of the game. They're attractive, in a crappy sorta way.
3) The gameplay is fantastic. Sometimes it's easy, and sometimes it's hard, but it varies enough to keep things challenging and entertaining the entire time you play.
4) It has a lot of elements that a lot of 3rd party developers could take a hint from. A simple and smart stealth system, a balanced currency/magic system, and a varied number of skills and weapons to allow several different approaches to the way you play.

Positives about the game:
Fun and varied gameplay
High replay value
Very atmoshpheric with the creepy sounds and lovecraftian inspiration
NOT a minecraft clone despite similar graphics
Not super difficult, a good introduction to the roguelike genre
Hardcore mode for those who want a  challenge

Negatives:
Some might be put off by the minecraft-ish graphics

That's pretty much it, any other grievances probably have more to do with the genre than with the game itself. It's pretty light on story and lore, but that's typical of games of this genre so I can't hold that against it.

Despite the similar graphical styling, the only common factor of Eldritch and Minecraft is the slight sense of dread while exploring unknown areas. I'd recommend it if you're a fan of Spelunky or Dishonored, but it's a must buy if you're a fan of both. Controller support is excellent, though keyboard and mouse work equally well.

reviewerDisplayName: S H O O B E R
reviewText: Only just started playing and I love it. The graphical style really fits and the gameplay is solid. What really sells it for me though is the ambience. The music and ambient noises are skin-crawlingly creepy and make traversing through a dungeon much tenser then it otherwise would be. Wonderful stuff.

TL;DR - This game's definitely worth playing, but not necessarily beating, depending on how much time you can put into it. How-Rogue-like-you-like-it?

For what it's worth, I'd say this is more of a horror game that uses elements like procedural generation, permadeath and the inability to save to enhance the experience rather than a true Rogue-like (or Rogue-lite) game. Elements such as the changes to the level layout and item locations each time you play it, as well as excellent sound design on the echoing cries of enemies and some nice touches in the art style (specifically how the subtle bulges on the walls warp the straight lines on them as the camera moves, making them seem to 'writhe') help build a sense of unease and dread as you creep around. As a Lovecraft fan I was delighted by recognizing the different creatures as enemies and appreciated the theming of the level around its elder being (the dry colours of Nyarlathotep, the 'wetness' of Dagon etc), though they're interesting enough that they wouldn't be lost on someone more casually aware of the mythos.

This all makes the game worth playing (at least, I think so), but is it worth beating? I mentioned the permadeath, and that will be the big 'make or break' for many players. In order to beat this game you have to finish all three of the 'main' stages (more have been added in patches since release, but I don't believe they count) AND the final level, all on one life. You can save and quit to pick up on where you left off, and deposit money you find in certain places for later that carries over, but you start from the beginning with nothing upon death. For example the furthest I got was beating the Dagon stage and half of Nyarlathotep before I died, and upon respawning my having won Dagon was undone. For those unfamiliar with Rogue-likes this may be a table-flipping moment; for those who know the score, that's part of the thrill. This means however that in order to beat the game you'll have to keep playing over and over until the circumstances to achieve it are just right (or the stars are correctly alligned"
date: if you will) or to have played so much of the game that you've memorized all the enemy and boss behaviours and all the possible hazards AND don't get screwed by the RNG. This is further reinforced with the Steam Achievements the game offers - beat the game in under 10 minutes
recommended: beat it without taking any damage
hoursPlayed: collect 9
voteText: 999 coins etc. One can hardly blame a developer for wanting players to play a lot of their game
helpfulPercent: but for some this may be more time than they can put in.\n\nFor the Lovecraft fan who's less inclined towards this genre it's still worth giving a go if it's on sale for the ambience and tension of the first few attempts
votesHelpful: but if you're seriously inclined towards Roguelikes
votesTotal: or are a Completionist
votesFunny: take a look at some of the other reviews on here to see what the game's long-term prospects are. I liked it
commentsCount: I'll keep playing it

Pros:
- Exciting gameplay with high replay value
- Randomly generated with at least six different tilesets and themes
- In addition to items there are accessories and magics that serve as passive and alternative active abilities

Cons:
- Poor item variety.  You've got two throwables, two guns, two food items, two questionably healthy food items, two melee items, and two mobility items.
- Poor tutorial.  Doesn't bother to explain how the map works or what the Asylum is.

Overall 8/10.  The gameplay as a roguelite allows it to overcome the poor item variety and the lack of a tutorial is only a temporary handicap.  It's pretty great.

Let's start by getting this out of the way: yes, this looks like a Minecraft mod.  Is it?  Could be, I don't know.  But it doesn't play like one, and that's what's important to me.

Eldrich is a game about dying.  Explore 5 Lovecraftan levels full of horrifying creatures and less ammo than you need.  It does a pretty good job of balancing giving you the power to fight back, but still feeling terrified when you see certain enemies.

My biggest criticism is that it's a bit Euclidian for  a Lovecraft game.  But it's a nice, simple survival game with some scary monsters, and technically a plot.  Multiple endings, even, if you can get that far.

This isn't the greatest game ever, but if you can get it for a few bucks, or in a bundle, you can definitely have  a lot of fun with it.

Don't let the graphics fool you- some of the monsters may look cute, but this game has a wonderful sense of eerie atmosphere that plays up suspense with each creak. The sound is expertly used in this game, where you can hear heavy breathing of a monster lurking nearby as you try to crouch just around the corner. Sends chills down my spine each time.

For a rouge-like, this game is more about stealth and trying to get the most out of the few resources you can cobble together. It provides a fresh challenge while refraining from feeling too difficult to impede on your fun. While playing, the hours will melt away faster than the flesh off of your smiling face.

But the gentle look of the art betrays the feelings you can get when you know a monster is nearby. overall, this is a fun game worth the humble price tag.

Personally, I love this game. I do agree that originally, it was really short. I was SUPER excited when I found out that they included the mountains of madness... Which I haven't beaten, of course.

What scares me about this most of all is the sounds. The constant sound of them and the feel that I don't really know what's going on is awful. There is nothing worst than the sound of a shoggoth somewhere in the level, and you've got no idea where or how many there are. Even worst is when its wife is the shop owne, and you decide to steal. *shudders*

The game can be short, sweet, and to the point. This can mean that you've won by being one smart little sh**, or that you died. Repeatedly. It's definitely a roguelike in that when you die... You start all over. So don't die.

I question myself whether it's worth its listed price. Right now, with the MOuntains of Madness, I think it is. I wouldn't mind more updates in the future, say, adding more notes and minor references to Lovecraft's works. This could be in secrets, too, and in maybe a couple new weaons. Doesn't have to be fancy; like, a special type of bladed weapon in the sandy level, and so on and so forth.

That said, above all else, I do recommend this game- IF you like Lovecraft's works. Otherwise, you may not get it, and it may not be your taste. Lovecraft isn't nearly as dry as Poe was, but he can definitely be dry. This game corporates his type of fear- that you are vastly out-gunned, out-manned, and just out of your league.

Eldrich is a 3D, first person, horror RPG inspired by H.P. Lovecraft, the father of cosmic horror. Navigate and survive in a randomly generated Minecraft styled world and fight different monsters, from simple cultists to fishpeople to the unkillable shoggoths. Heck, you may even see Chuthulu (not actually sure if you do) himself! Use differnt weapons to fight said creatures; bottles, rocks, knives, and if your lucky then you may find some TNT.  Be stealthy and and survive or not be stealthy and decreace your chances to survive.\n\nEldrich is a great buy and I would recomend it any day.

Eldritch combines stealth, survival, and exploration in ways that I have yet to experience in other games. While the normal campaign is rather short and easy, the new game plus mode will put your roguelike skills to the test. I would have preferred having access to this mode from the beginning of the game, but even as is, I would say that this is a great buy for roguelike veterans. While it might not have a deep RPG system or a lengthy item list, destructible environments and some great random level generation make Eldritch a unique experience.

Eldritch is pure amazing. Seriously. If you melted your computer while running it, it would probably end up as a pool of liquid gold... (actually, don't try that.) I love this game. I've played many roguelikes before, so this game was a bit simple to start with, but after your first playthrough a feature titled New Game+ amps the dificulty up to where it should be (at least for a roguelike). The game is practically Dishonored developed by Mojang, allowing you to slide, mantle, and sprint all in a first person prospective. Buy this game if you like Dishonored. Buy this game if you like roguelikes. Screw it, just BUY this game becuase it's AMAZING.

An absolutely wonderful experience. This is the type of game you play to just lose yourself in for a while, finding new secrets and strategies to make use of in your gameplay, getting a little frustrated whenever you have to turn back, but always gritting your teeth and being ready to start a new I was skeptical of how I would like the game being in first person and having the rather old school graphics, but both work incredibly well, giving you a lot of chance to immerse yourelf in the complexity of the dungeons you explore and their lore. I would like to give an especially big kudos to the wonderful sound design of the game, which not only invokes it's Lovecraftian themes, but kept me on edge throughout, never knowing if it was an actual enemy or just the echoes of evil in the level I'm exploring. There's a lot of fun to be had here, akin to Rogue Legacy or FTL, where you just keep playing for hours and when it's time to leave you whisper Just a little bit more...""

It gives me jump scares with the monsters, like the Jumping Frog. It is really addicting saying how this game you choose where you want to go with 4 maps, scavenge for items, steal or buy from shops,  unlock magic, and much more. If you like classic games, Minecraft, and FPS, this is for you to buy.

A very fun and mysterious game that makes you addicted then wet yourself

Personally, I love this game. I do agree that originally, it was really short. I was SUPER excited when I found out that they included the mountains of madness... Which I haven't beaten, of course.

What scares me about this most of all is the sounds. The constant sound of them and the feel that I don't really know what's going on is awful. There is nothing worst than the sound of a shoggoth somewhere in the level, and you've got no idea where or how many there are. Even worst is when its wife is the shop owne, and you decide to steal. *shudders*

The game can be short, sweet, and to the point. This can mean that you've won by being one smart little sh**, or that you died. Repeatedly. It's definitely a roguelike in that when you die... You start all over. So don't die.

I question myself whether it's worth its listed price. Right now, with the MOuntains of Madness, I think it is. I wouldn't mind more updates in the future, say, adding more notes and minor references to Lovecraft's works. This could be in secrets, too, and in maybe a couple new weaons. Doesn't have to be fancy; like, a special type of bladed weapon in the sandy level, and so on and so forth.

That said, above all else, I do recommend this game- IF you like Lovecraft's works. Otherwise, you may not get it, and it may not be your taste. Lovecraft isn't nearly as dry as Poe was, but he can definitely be dry. This game corporates his type of fear- that you are vastly out-gunned, out-manned, and just out of your league.
You want something creepy? you lovecraft? (huhuhuh see what i did there?)\nthen get this. also the lizardmen statues are EVIL. you'll know what i mean when you get to it.

Eldritch combines stealth, survival, and exploration in ways that I have yet to experience in other games. While the normal campaign is rather short and easy, the new game plus mode will put your roguelike skills to the test. I would have preferred having access to this mode from the beginning of the game, but even as is, I would say that this is a great buy for roguelike veterans. While it might not have a deep RPG system or a lengthy item list, destructible environments and some great random level generation make Eldritch a unique experience.

This game is quite some fun, though it's not going to be for everyone. The story is pretty simple, wake up in library  with no memories and the only door locked with the keys in books that you must get through. While the gameplay is also simple the difficulty quickly works it's way up as you go through the the 3 books, with various challengs unique to each one. Once you get the keys you can leave, and you unock the new game plus mode which make the game much harder. The enmeies are quite varied and take plenty of unfluence from the love craftian side of horor. With basic cultists at the start, working you way all the way to unkown horrors that I really can't explain besides godzilla.\n\nThis is a very caual rouge like. Death actaully means something, and dying means getting sent all the way to the start since there is no way to save besides starting at the point you left the game. If your looking for a nice game to play for a good 30 minutes or so, should definatley pick this up.

Eldritch is a good game.

You begin in the Library which is basicly a coozy questhub.
Then you have these 3 Books that teleports you to different dungeons/temples.
All these dungeons and Temples holds 3 'levels' with 3 floors in each.
Some requires that you do something special to get out, some requires only that you get to the exit.
Once that is done, you find a Soul and a Book back to the library, once that is done you Unlock a new dungeon.

I was sceptical at first, given the graphics and... yeah, the graphics.
The graphics wasn't a problem though, I was a bit put off on the part where Horrors are somewhat cute.
Even afterwards I can say that the game had been alot better with more horrifying Horrors.

That being said, the game still scared the everliving ♥♥♥♥ out of me with jumpscares and blasphemous noises.
If you are an easily frightend one with a feign heart, then this game will be hell for you.

A simple, first-person RPG inspired by the works of H.P. Lovecraft. The sound and the visuals definitely give you a creepy Lovecraft vibe.  With only a few points of health, you're never more than a couple of hits from death so the tension is always high.  The interaction with the environment is similar to minecraft (but much more limited).

I reccomend this game because I love the setting and I feel like I got my moneys worth (bought on sale). However, I do wish there was more content as far as equipment and maybe some more backround into the hp lovecraft universe. A fun game, I just wish their was more.

I absolutely love this game. It has a sort of minecrafty asthetic to it even though block placement isn't really a part of the game. To be totally far, however, there are a few items that actually will allow you to place/destroy blocks.

This game is set in the Cuthulu mythos, but it doesn't really have much to do with any actual lovecraft story. Lovecraftian monsters and archetecture just fill out the level design.

If I had to pick a game to compare this to, I'd have to go with spelunky. This game really does feel like a 3D spelunky. You start on the top floor of the level and have to progress through traps and enemies in order to reach the bottom.

On a serious note this is a First Person Shooter based off of the writings of Howard Phillip Lovecraft. You start as a Librarian of sorts, in a mysterious library with books littered about teeming with information. You find out that you are bound to this place an act as a gaurdian agaisnt the terrors of the Old Ones. There are some books that give off a shimmer and act as a portal to another dimension inhabited by Cultists, Dæmons and other Horrors that could plague the mind and soul. You have a chest that can store Artifacts which act as currency, the Deep Ones seem to cherish them and some will act neutral to even barter for them. Exploring these non-Euclidean realms takes a toll on ones perspective, they are never the same and have no definite structure. If you perish you simply re-awaken in the library, any Artifacts stored and items left here will stay, yet anything collected will be gone. Entering once again into these worlds that seem wrong, a strange tingle or sense just behind the nose, a scent of sorts. In the many works and studies these scholars or gaurdians what have you, a theory of pineal gland enlargement and extra-sensory perception is documented. Another book, going through them its never the same and there are so many! I went down through at least three gateways, faced what seemed to be, as best as I can describe it through my recent studies is a Shoggoth. I was terrified! At first it didn't make much sense, those Deep Ones could just be mutants or an actual bipedal, semi-intelligent race that evolved along with Humankind. That could be possible, right? But this, this was different. At first I struck out wildly with my dagger, nothing  but violent screams and lashing tentacle like appendages. I could see its gnashing maw and those unearthly eyes that seemed to see infinitly deep into my very being. My mind broke, I could somehow understand but to only comprehend I must let go of my sanity. I pushed away, firing my pistol wildly into its oozing form and managed to safely get away...or so I thought. Tekeli-li Shoggoth, Tekeli-li Shoggoth. I tossed a bundle of dynamite I found towards its protoplasmic form and missed my mark, it detonating meters behind the creature. Stell'bsna wgah'n shagg tharanak shugg syha'h. Things are different now, I haven't been here before but was there anyways. How pages have I read so far? Am I reading or am I acutally inside them? Honestly I can't remember if I dreamt that after reading some of these books or it acutally happened. But there is a dagger and pistol on the counter that I don't recall having earlier. Was I asleep? Where would I sleep? Geb agl ehye'bthnk c fhtagn ee. They can't reach me through these books can they? I have all the lights on in the library that I could find, I remember reading something about right angles, the way perceived space effected time, and how time could catch up to you....hunt you down itself. ph'nglui mglw'nafh Cthulhu R'lyeh wgah'nagl fhtagn. Very familiar it is now. No I understand. No, it is alright I will continue. There are many things to do now. Mana-Yood-Sushai h'fhtagn....syha'h...syha'h.....syha'h

EDIT: Upon re-reading this, I think I might have sold this game a bit short, so I'll add a little more:
Re-playability is huge, it's one of those games where you think you know how to do something until you get painted into a corner and try something else and realize you could have done it a different way all along.

A fantastic rouge-like styled after the classic horror novels by H.P. Lovecraft with difficulty only matched by its tense atmosphere and wonderful diversity in each play. It's by no means simple and you most certainly won't complete it in your first ten, twenty, fifty attempts! Heck, even with a huge statement like that I've only put a hearty 12+ hours into it so it's most certainly learnable." It all relies on how quickly you can gracefully adapt to the game's changing environments... And I do mean gracefully. After mastering the game's controls (running
hoursPlayed: leaping and all that will be used quite frequently) you almost feel like you're being thrown around the map! On top of that you have a simple but hardly repetitive group of enemies to deal with ranging from fish-men to flying... organs? It's easy to conclude "well this is just impossible" but the game actually does have quite a few ways to completing it! Throwing yourself into the storm over and over won't do you much good so it's always good to take on a strategy. I've recently found stealthiness to be the ultimate path but you do have to be ready to lose some 35-50 minutes instantly from simple mistakes. If you don't feel like taking on all "three" worlds at once (it's difficult beyond comprehension but I've done it multiple times!) you can also try the Mountains of Madness: 10 levels of pure hell to retrieve your plane keys (keeping close to the books as always) and then heading all 10 levels back up to the surface! Fun alternative
helpfulPercent:
It's super tense and you'll get lost more than once as it begins to feel more like a labyrinth.

SPOILERS/TIPS

A great way to start any campaign is by grabbing the compass from Dagon [The first world ] and returning to The Library. Next you'll probably want to do the Trick or Treat world [ the pumpkin in the bar area ] be prepared to spend about 2-5 minutes here gathering materials for your next run! After you've grabbed a grappling hook and a gun with over 15+ ammo
votesHelpful:
return to The Library and re-enter Dagon. Complete the first world as so:
[for beginners]:
-Always look for a way down and try not to re-enter previously entered rooms
-Avoid looting dead bodies... and don't waste ammo on those that don't need to be killed!
-Press Z to throw items (great if you need to drop your gun/grappling hook for a takeout punch)
-Hold spacebar to lift yourself over ledges! It took me almost 8 hours to realize this... it'll save you keys and such
votesTotal: allow you into new rooms
votesFunny:
and save you from getting stuck in holes
-run and press C (the crouch button for sneaking) to do a power-slide! You'll look cool AND it'll make your jumps longer!

[For returning players]
-Approach levels slowly! Pay attention to the map! Knowing your surroundings is almost necessary to escaping any level
-If the opportunity to rush through a floor is available then you should most certainly take it; especially in later levels where there are tons of baddies chasing you down
-don't hug walls unless you're sneaking; enemies can easily get the jump on you
-try not to forget to peek around corners if you're uncertain how safe a room is (C+E/Q). You can shoot and cast spells when you're in this position
-It took me nearly 70 attempts to complete the game and I have no doubt it'll take plenty less for you. Keep at it

Surprisingly creepy and very original, but short. The atmosphere in Eldritch is great. The art, ambient sounds, and music all come together to create a truly unique setting. When I first played Eldritch I was torn between hating the merciless permadeath features and absolutely loving the lovely (ish)\nvoxel art and action-packed caving (sort of) then I forgot it and for a whileit lay dormant in my Steam Library, then it was rediscovered just as the Mountains of Madness free expansion was released. When I rebooted it and tried after a month I was surprised by how much more I understood about the mechanics and ways to defeat the enemies and in an half hour I had unlocked the second book! Overall I would say that if you don't mind dying over and over with no saves or item recovery, definately buy it.

I have a particular interest in first-person realtime roguelike dungeon crawlers. If you've stuck around for that 8-word (or 5 combo-word) genre description, stick around for more because I'm gonna tell you what I think Eldritch does right and wrong by that genre.

I want to sing some praises of the game.
Character Control - Lean (left and right), crouch, slide (run/crouch), mantle (ledge climb).
As simple as these four mechanics are, I feel they are essential for making a player feel like they are actually interacting with the environment instead of just... sliding through it with WSAD and jump alone. Third person action games are practically all Prince of Persia with the amount of climbing you do, but first-person games rarely attempt much. I appreciate Eldritch's effort here.

Interesting Enemies - There are a couple that really force you to play differently, and one in a way that I had never seen in a game before. Others provide some fun flavor that's just enjoyable to interact with.

Stealth - Most roguelikes don't feature any meaningful stealth mechanic. Thanks to the character control, Eldritch is very rewarding of careful, thoughtful advancement through its mazes. Since your character has little HP and healing is not terribly common, remaining in control of how you advance is essential to a sense of agency in a game that is otherwise random.

Here are some Meh issues -

Uninteresting Enemies - Most of the enemies have a boring fireball attack as their only offense. They are also highly predictable when pursuing you.

Shops - Too sparse and expensive. The bank" system which allows you store the game's currency from life to life isn't easy enough to access to make spending money worthwhile
date: which is a shame because some of the items really improve the experience.\n\nLength and Difficulty - After 5 hours and only 8 deaths
recommended: I beat Eldritch.  After you learn the enemy behavior
hoursPlayed: deaths only result from stupid mistakes or unlucky coincidences
voteText: so it doesn't give that broad sense of growth and education that good roguelikes have. The game also allows you to collect orbs to unlock "shortcuts" to the later dungeons (there are 3 to unlock)
helpfulPercent: but to actually beat the game you have to collect all the orbs in a single life anyway. So the shortcuts are only practical for practice
votesHelpful: not for actual progress. The result is that the length of the game feels artificial and tedious
votesTotal: rather than hard-earned and rewarding.\n\nThe Ending - Getting to the end of a roguelike typically takes a lot of effort and it's nice to feel like your effort is tracked somewhere or you have some incentive to... do better or something. Eldritch says "you won and it's anticlimactic
votesFunny:
in not so many words.

Feature Light - The game feels a little hollow, probably as a result of lacking variety in the game mechanics, enemy, and level event variety. This makes me appreciate the control mechanics even more.

Anyway, I'm glad I played Eldritch. It's made me aware of problems I'd have never considered for my own interest in the genre and it had its moments of excitement and inspiration.  I'll definitely continue to play Eldritch as they release more updates.

This game is pretty gosh-darn neat. It's hard to describe, but my best approximation would be a first-person, Lovecraft-flavored Binding of Isaac. If you haven't played Isaac, just know that it's a 'roguelike', which is to say every playthrough is randomly generated.
The Good- It's a roguelike, so it has a lot of replay value.
There are a lot of items and pieces of equipment you can use, so there's some fun to be had customizing your loadout.
The atmosphere is pretty effective (relatively speaking), and I appreciated the lack of music (which enhanced the survival horror vibe.)
Interesting setup, concept, and general excecution.

The Bad- It's a roguelike, so you're trapped at the mercy of the Random Number God. He is not a benevolent diety.
It's pretty limited graphically - it's stylized, and everything looks like it's supposed to, but the polygons and weird animation (especially on the arms) means it's pretty unlikely to scare you.
There are a few absolutely game-breaking loadouts that are pretty easy to get in any given run, making it a cakewalk once they've been discovered.
The game is, barring RNG-induced errors, very easy overall. The maker of the game did say he intended it to be that way, but the execution is rather jarring - once you learn the basic rules and patterns of the game, all conflicts boil down to either speedbumps on the road to victory (walk at monster, slash with knife) or nightmarish, luck-based impossibility (*******ING LIZARD STATUES).
The story has a bit of potential, but the delivery (text screens that pop up narrating the action) is completely uninvolving.

On the whole, this is a fun game. It's not a deep parable about the meaning of existence or a titan of gameplay innovation, but it's an interesting use of time, if nothing else.
H.P. Lovecraft themed dungeons in a roguelike package. Great gameplay and fantastic replay value.

From the description of the game and the blocky graphics, I expected a lot less than I got. The game is actually challenging with an entertaining mysterious storyline that you can find if you're so inclined. It's not required to complete the game, but it helps. What I thought was a shooting Lovecraftian game turned out to require a lot more stealth than I expected, as well as strategy.

Dying starts the entire game over completely, and since every 'dungeon' is randomly generated I suppose you could call it 'rogue-like' but only in a very broad sense since it's so short. You'll get maybe a day or two of good play out of this, depending on your skill level.

The enemies are entertaining and some require strategy to defeat. I say defeat, because quite a few of them are un-killable. This doesn't hinder the game, it actually helps the challenge.

If you're looking for a fun Lovecraftian horror however, this is not it. It borrows from the Mythos, but only in a very loose way. The names of all involved have been changed to protect the innocent.

Storyline: 4/10 - Not necessary, but good none the less.
Graphics: 4/10 - You do not play a game like this for what they loosely refer to as 'graphics'.
Sound: 6/10 - I don't actually remember any music, but hte sounds and ambiance are fantastic.
Gameplay: 8/10 - Frustrating, challenging, thoughtful. Very worth it.

This game is an absolute delight. The first time invokes terror, a terror that, like many games, you eventually dispel as you finally make your way to your first victory, only to return when you're low on health, and hear something around the corner. The moments of fear are gripping, the moments of action thrilling. There is a true lucidity of design here, it feels as though everything is in its place for a reason. I felt satisfaction and anguish in equal measure, stabbing many a cultist in the back only to duck into a narrow crevasse a moment later, waiting for the sounds of a Shoggoth to recede into the distance. My blood has chilled as a monster of stone has spotted me, and I have stalked through R'lyeh, fearful of waking its denizens. Immersive and well worth the price, this game comes highly recommended. Truly a study in maximising minimal resources, from a game designer's perspective. Here I thought I would never encounter pixel-induced terror, but Minor Key Games has proven me wrong.

A neat little timesink that's shockingly enjoyable and atmospheric considering its texture quality.\n\nIn the first 3 minutes the game had me transported to a labyrinthian maze, launching and swinging from grappling wires, and getting eaten by Shoggoth.  Eldritch is a sweet little Lovecraftian loveletter in the guise of an FPS puzzler.  The overall structure of the world is hub-based, with a library serving as your home base where you may teleport to various realms in search of supplies, powerups, and monsters to battle.  The levels are sprawling monoliths with varying (and sometimes destructable) terrain; and the soundtrack and effects are genuinely creepy, creating a surprising amount of immersion in a game whose texturing would make Wolfenstein 3D proud.

Pros: Great atmosphere, interesting and complex level design, Very fluid and responsive controls, Interesting concept especially based on an author,

Cons: Lose all your items if you die, missions can be quite repetitive, and a bit expensive for an indie game

Overall,  this game is well worth the money.  I would highly recommend this game.

This is potentially a great game; I had fun for a while, the set up and storyline are both simple and wonderful; but... there isn't a particularly huge amount of content here. You could realistically experience what the game has to offer within the first thirty minutes of playing.\n\nAll enemies bar the stone statues are very simple, similar, and non-threatening; the item set is quite small, and the levels quite often look the same: This all adds up to a randomly generated game where it doesn't matter that it's randomly generated, because everything is so similar that there's no room for any kind of strategy or unique experiences. It's a missed opportunity.

Don't let its unpolished, Minecraft-like veneer fool you - this game is a great little rogue-lite set in the weird worlds of H. P. Lovecraft. I was sucked in almost immediately, and have been playing it non-stop since I installed it a week or so ago. The randomly-generated nature of the game lends replayability, and the enemy design is awesome. Hands down the best thing about this game is its music - ambient guitar tracks lend a strange, spooky, warped atmosphere that really makes you feel like you're in the Lost Tomb of Nyarlathotep or warndering around R'lyeh, exploring worlds that should not be and that humans were not meant to walk in. The atmosphere of the game's worlds is genuinely unnerving in some levels, particularly the Cthulhu and Mountains of Madness levels - the first time you hear a Star Spawn wheeze or see an Elder Thing or Mi-go come wobbling after you out of the fog is the last time you're going to want to.

If I do have one gripe about the game itself, it's that it may be an unforgiving challenge for newcomers to the idea of rogue and rogue-lite gameplay, and can be tough with its enemies often doing more damage than your overall health. However, there are plenty of ways to boost your health or give yourself an edge, provided you have the artifacts - in-game money you get by looting corpses and exploring around - meaning that the game's not too tough given enough practice.

One more thing - this Lovecraft fan is a little disappointed in the character model for the Mi-go in the Mountains of Madness chapter (they don't look very Mi-go-ish...), and is utterly confused as to why there are Lizardmen in Nyarlathotep's book (Yig is the snake/reptile Great Old One, Nyarly's actually an Outer God and much more powerful). I'm also confused about why there are two lower-level Lovecraftian deities (Cthulhu and Dagon) mixed in with Nyarlathotep, a much more powerful deity. Why not use Hastur or something, or use Cthulhu, Nyarly, and Yog-Sothoth or something? That's just the Lovecraft purist in me though, and definitely doesn't detract from the overall game in a way most people would notice.

Bottom line is this: This game is a great little rogue-lite for Lovecraft fans and those new to his works alike, or for anyone who likes a little Survival in their Cosmic Horror Story. It hits a good chunk of Lovecraftian themes right on the head, and it's definitely addicting for those who like a bit of challenge. I would recommend it, but not if you're not into rogue-lites/rogues or Lovecraftian Horror.

Eldritch, very brazenly the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child of Minecraft and Spelunky, bides its time, initially presenting itself as easy and cartoonish and a shameless coattail-rider, before blossoming into a sort of oddball terror . reviewText: A simple, first-person RPG inspired by the works of H.P. Lovecraft. The sound and the visuals definitely give you a creepy Lovecraft vibe. On a serious note this is a First Person Shooter based off of the writings of Howard Phillip Lovecraft. You start as a Librarian of sorts, in a mysterious library with books littered about teeming with information. You find out that you are bound to this place an act as a gaurdian agaisnt the terrors of the Old Ones. There are some books that give off a shimmer and act as a portal to another dimension inhabited by Cultists, Dæmons and other Horrors that could plague the mind and soul. You have a chest that can store Artifacts which act as currency, the Deep Ones seem to cherish them and some will act neutral to even barter for them. Exploring these non-Euclidean realms takes a toll on ones perspective, they are never the same and have no definite structure. If you perish you simply re-awaken in the library, any Artifacts stored and items left here will stay, yet anything collected will be gone. Entering once again into these worlds that seem wrong, a strange tingle or sense just behind the nose, a scent of sorts. In the many works and studies these scholars or gaurdians what have you, a theory of pineal gland enlargement and extra-sensory perception is documented. Another book, going through them its never the same and there are so many! I went down through at least three gateways, faced what seemed to be, as best as I can describe it through my recent studies is a Shoggoth. I was terrified! At first it didn't make much sense, those Deep Ones could just be mutants or an actual bipedal, semi-intelligent race that evolved along with Humankind. That could be possible, right? But this, this was different. At first I struck out wildly with my dagger, nothing  but violent screams and lashing tentacle like appendages. I could see its gnashing maw and those unearthly eyes that seemed to see infinitly deep into my very being. My mind broke, I could somehow understand but to only comprehend I must let go of my sanity. I pushed away, firing my pistol wildly into its oozing form and managed to safely get away...or so I thought. Tekeli-li Shoggoth, Tekeli-li Shoggoth. I tossed a bundle of dynamite I found towards its protoplasmic form and missed my mark, it detonating meters behind the creature. Stell'bsna wgah'n shagg tharanak shugg syha'h. Things are different now, I haven't been here before but was there anyways. How pages have I read so far? Am I reading or am I acutally inside them? Honestly I can't remember if I dreamt that after reading some of these books or it acutally happened. But there is a dagger and pistol on the counter that I don't recall having earlier. Was I asleep? Where would I sleep? Geb agl ehye'bthnk c fhtagn ee. They can't reach me through these books can they? I have all the lights on in the library that I could find, I remember reading something about right angles, the way perceived space effected time, and how time could catch up to you....hunt you down itself. ph'nglui mglw'nafh Cthulhu R'lyeh wgah'nagl fhtagn. Very familiar it is now. No I understand. No, it is alright I will continue. There are many things to do now. Mana-Yood-Sushai h'fhtagn....syha'h...syha'h.....syha'h
