Eldritch is a game that works out a bit however you want it to; what feels like a stellar fusion of ambient horror and rougelike for the slow and cautious can be an entirely different affair for the sort who wants to run in guns a-blazin'.  This results in a game where your experience can be highly personalized, which is far from a bad thing.

Eldritch has you taking on the role of a lone Librarian who must delve into sinister realms in their search of escape, dealing with Lovecraftian horrors while salvaging resources and managing whatever hand they're dealt.  The monster variety and what they bring to the table is impressive for the game's scope - one achievement tasks you with finishing the game in under ten minutes, so this is hardly the lengthiest of affairs, though there's a fair degree of difficulty in the obstacles one must overcome here, and that's ignoring the increased challenge of new game+ and newer areas released over time after the game's initial release.

And those extended additions are well worth mentioning: the main game sports three worlds and a final challenge to fight your way through, each with its own distinct flavor with regards to traps, archetecture and monster variety.  It's a solid package in and of itself, but the addition of a score-chasing, fast-paced scavenger hunt through the Asylum, the lengthy and absurdly challenging mountain expedition, and a fairly friendly bonus feast of a Halloween realm are all welcome additions, adding to the game's replayability and depth.

Eldritch isn't the prettiest thing you'll see by any stretch, but the audio atmosphere is strong, and the player's vulnerability only adds to the tension.  Your decisions as you progress greatly impact your odds of survival, and the obstacles you face are overwhelming in number.  Whether you choose to take your time and soak it all in carefully or run in screaming like a banshee, there's a lot here worth your attention.

A neat little timesink that's shockingly enjoyable and atmospheric considering its texture quality.\n\nIn the first 3 minutes the game had me transported to a labyrinthian maze, launching and swinging from grappling wires, and getting eaten by Shoggoth.  Eldritch is a sweet little Lovecraftian loveletter in the guise of an FPS puzzler.  The overall structure of the world is hub-based, with a library serving as your home base where you may teleport to various realms in search of supplies, powerups, and monsters to battle.  The levels are sprawling monoliths with varying (and sometimes destructable) terrain; and the soundtrack and effects are genuinely creepy, creating a surprising amount of immersion in a game whose texturing would make Wolfenstein 3D proud.

To think that I impulse-bought this in the last Steam sale... If I had only known I would enjoy it more than any of the big budget games I had been looking forward to I would have saved my money and bought a bunch of copies of Eldritch instead! If you're looking for a stealth-based, rogue-like with a heavy emphasis on 3D platforming and atmosphere, it doesn't get better than this. Most people look at a few screenshots, write it off as a Minecraft cash-in, and move on. The poor fools! They don't even know what they're missing!

One thing is true: the graphics are nothing special. They capture the very minimum of their subject and the surroundings. There are some nice color palettes though, and the blocky nature light is cast makes it very obvious if you can be seen or not. And although the textures are unimpressive, the random level design is just as fun to look at as it is to traverse. Thankfully the audio is spectacular. Echoed moans, gurgles, gasps follow you wherever you go and always make you wonder what's just below your feet. The minimalist soundtrack is just as compelling. Obviously it's not a toe-tapping good time, but it certainly puts you on edge and makes you feel... Well, weird.

'Weird' is really the name of the game here. This isn't meant to be made into a reaction compilation on your Let's Play channel. It focuses on the 'Weird Tales' aspect in favor of a more frightening experience. For those of you who have been waiting patiently for a Lovecraftian game to mean more than fishmen and tentacle monsters yelling Boo!"

When I saw the trailer I though, Another Voxel, Minecraft-Like spin off but I was wrong, this game is a dungeon crawler randomly generated with not scary, but unfomfortable atmosphere filled with monsters and abominations. It has destructible enviroment and simple stealth mechanics that could be used to avoid or kill enemies.\n\nIt's challenging ill give it that, but it's often frustrating because if you die you lose everything that is not stored in a bank. A mod support would be really nice.

Wat was dat der Dæmons name???? Nyarlathotep?  *dueling banjos plays*





On a serious note this is a First Person Shooter based off of the writings of Howard Phillip Lovecraft. You start as a Librarian of sorts, in a mysterious library with books littered about teeming with information. You find out that you are bound to this place an act as a gaurdian agaisnt the terrors of the Old Ones. There are some books that give off a shimmer and act as a portal to another dimension inhabited by Cultists, Dæmons and other Horrors that could plague the mind and soul. You have a chest that can store Artifacts which act as currency, the Deep Ones seem to cherish them and some will act neutral to even barter for them. Exploring these non-Euclidean realms takes a toll on ones perspective, they are never the same and have no definite structure. If you perish you simply re-awaken in the library, any Artifacts stored and items left here will stay, yet anything collected will be gone. Entering once again into these worlds that seem wrong, a strange tingle or sense just behind the nose, a scent of sorts. In the many works and studies these scholars or gaurdians what have you, a theory of pineal gland enlargement and extra-sensory perception is documented. Another book, going through them its never the same and there are so many! I went down through at least three gateways, faced what seemed to be, as best as I can describe it through my recent studies is a Shoggoth. I was terrified! At first it didn't make much sense, those Deep Ones could just be mutants or an actual bipedal, semi-intelligent race that evolved along with Humankind. That could be possible, right? But this, this was different. At first I struck out wildly with my dagger, nothing  but violent screams and lashing tentacle like appendages. I could see its gnashing maw and those unearthly eyes that seemed to see infinitly deep into my very being. My mind broke, I could somehow understand but to only comprehend I must let go of my sanity. I pushed away, firing my pistol wildly into its oozing form and managed to safely get away...or so I thought. Tekeli-li Shoggoth, Tekeli-li Shoggoth. I tossed a bundle of dynamite I found towards its protoplasmic form and missed my mark, it detonating meters behind the creature. Stell'bsna wgah'n shagg tharanak shugg syha'h. Things are different now, I haven't been here before but was there anyways. How pages have I read so far? Am I reading or am I acutally inside them? Honestly I can't remember if I dreamt that after reading some of these books or it acutally happened. But there is a dagger and pistol on the counter that I don't recall having earlier. Was I asleep? Where would I sleep? Geb agl ehye'bthnk c fhtagn ee. They can't reach me through these books can they? I have all the lights on in the library that I could find, I remember reading something about right angles, the way perceived space effected time, and how time could catch up to you....hunt you down itself. ph'nglui mglw'nafh Cthulhu R'lyeh wgah'nagl fhtagn. Very familiar it is now. No I understand. No, it is alright I will continue. There are many things to do now. Mana-Yood-Sushai h'fhtagn....syha'h...syha'h.....syha'h

Eldritch is a Rouge lite exploartion game set in a Lovecraftian world and done in a Voxel graphic style.  Think sillent hill if it was done in the minecraft engine.

You search several worlds inspired by the works of Lovecraft trying to decend or acend further into the level until you find the exit. along the way you'll encounter a number of monsters like, deep ones, mummies, shogotohs, flying polyops ect.

The game is okay. they did a decent job of depicting a Lovecrafting atmosphere and your character is very weak leading to a real sense of danger. you feel small and helpless which is exactly how you should feel in a lovecraft game.

saddly the voxel graphics take somthing away from the experince and theres only a handful of enemy types and only a couple are particularly intresting.  There a number of items and weapons you can get but these too are limited and most of them you'll ignore in faovor of more pratical things like the gun and dagger.  The rouge like nature of the game does add replayablity but greatly limits what can be done with the narrative which is somthing you don't want to skimp out on in a lovecraft game.

If your a fan of Lovecraft this might be an intresting distraction for a bit but you'll likely grow bored of it quickly.  If your just looking for a strange indy horror game, there are worse games then this.  If your looking for a great story or a more dynamic game...i'd say get sillent hill or fatal frame.

It was fun for awhile but i don't see myself replaying it anytime soon.
As a big fan of Lovecraft's writing, this was a lot of fun.  If you don't know Lovecraft's work, you probably won't get the same enjoyment out of it, but it still should be fun.
The what you can do in Eldritch trailer forgot one thing, getting killed by your own thrown rock. 10/10 would get betrayed by pet rock again.

A very fun rougelike which can be genuinely tense and exciting at its best. Manages to be a challenge without being too difficult. Has a high replay value.

The esthetic also does it no harm. Some people might object to how cute the enemies can be when they are supposed to be lovecraftian horrors. But I think it works well because it is unique. The simplcity of the graphics also serves gameplay and the game runs very well.

Looking forward to New Game +, and hard mode.

All in all pretty good.

EDIT: Upon re-reading this, I think I might have sold this game a bit short, so I'll add a little more:
Re-playability is huge, it's one of those games where you think you know how to do something until you get painted into a corner and try something else and realize you could have done it a different way all along.

I love it for that. The first few times I got AAAAlmost all the way made the endgame SO much sweeter, and there is plenty of super secret stuff to keep the hardest of cores coming back with a ridiculous amount of added difficulty added on top.

A fantastic rouge-like styled after the classic horror novels by H.P. Lovecraft with difficulty only matched by its tense atmosphere and wonderful diversity in each play. It's by no means simple and you most certainly won't complete it in your first ten, twenty, fifty attempts! Heck, even with a huge statement like that I've only put a hearty 12+ hours into it so it's most certainly learnable." It all relies on how quickly you can gracefully adapt to the game's changing environments... And I do mean gracefully. After mastering the game's controls (running
hoursPlayed: leaping and all that will be used quite frequently) you almost feel like you're being thrown around the map! On top of that you have a simple but hardly repetitive group of enemies to deal with ranging from fish-men to flying... organs? It's easy to conclude "well this is just impossible" but the game actually does have quite a few ways to completing it! Throwing yourself into the storm over and over won't do you much good so it's always good to take on a strategy. I've recently found stealthiness to be the ultimate path but you do have to be ready to lose some 35-50 minutes instantly from simple mistakes. If you don't feel like taking on all "three" worlds at once (it's difficult beyond comprehension but I've done it multiple times!) you can also try the Mountains of Madness: 10 levels of pure hell to retrieve your plane keys (keeping close to the books as always) and then heading all 10 levels back up to the surface! Fun alternative
helpfulPercent:
It's super tense and you'll get lost more than once as it begins to feel more like a labyrinth.

SPOILERS/TIPS

A great way to start any campaign is by grabbing the compass from Dagon [The first world ] and returning to The Library. Next you'll probably want to do the Trick or Treat world [ the pumpkin in the bar area ] be prepared to spend about 2-5 minutes here gathering materials for your next run! After you've grabbed a grappling hook and a gun with over 15+ ammo
votesHelpful:
return to The Library and re-enter Dagon. Complete the first world as so:
[for beginners]:
-Always look for a way down and try not to re-enter previously entered rooms
-Avoid looting dead bodies... and don't waste ammo on those that don't need to be killed!
-Press Z to throw items (great if you need to drop your gun/grappling hook for a takeout punch)
-Hold spacebar to lift yourself over ledges! It took me almost 8 hours to realize this... it'll save you keys and such
votesTotal: allow you into new rooms
votesFunny:
and save you from getting stuck in holes
-run and press C (the crouch button for sneaking) to do a power-slide! You'll look cool AND it'll make your jumps longer!

[For returning players]
-Approach levels slowly! Pay attention to the map! Knowing your surroundings is almost necessary to escaping any level
-If the opportunity to rush through a floor is available then you should most certainly take it; especially in later levels where there are tons of baddies chasing you down
-don't hug walls unless you're sneaking; enemies can easily get the jump on you
-try not to forget to peek around corners if you're uncertain how safe a room is (C+E/Q). You can shoot and cast spells when you're in this position
-It took me nearly 70 attempts to complete the game and I have no doubt it'll take plenty less for you. Keep at it

reviewText: I bought this game looking for an interesting take on cosmic horror and at first I felt a little let down. I played it a small bit and kept dying because i just didnt get it. I recently came back and read through the books and took a look at the game as a whole and i started to love it. It for me was really quite fun, it has a creepy atmosphere as you get deeper into the game and some enemies are really quie scary. I personally just love how this game plays out and if your a fan of lovecraft's work then you may find this peculiar game to you liking.

This game is enormous fun. It's kind of a fresh game -- the low quality graphics contrasts wonderfully with the creepy sound design, and it's unabashedly a game. It's short too, which I like -- expect to beat it in a couple hours and feel satisfied.

I did jump at times (the monsters are creepy!) when a moving statue got me, or a monster followed me into a room.

Here's hoping for an Eldritch 2!

reviewText: Don't let the old school graphics throw you off, this is a modern game under the hood. I'm really liking it so far.

A 3D spelunky minecraft looking survival game with an eerie atmosphere.\nGives a good alternative to the jump scare survival horror genre too as its randomly seeded worlds mean a different game every time & the scares come as a result of chance and exploration not from some predetermined trigger point that you know is comming.

I'm going to give this game a thumbs up because I think it's interesting and original and I want to show some support for it. After putting several hours in to it, I have to say, it feels somehow incomplete. It's also fairly difficult. The combination of these two things make for diminishing returns. I read a review of this game that described it as a 3D roguelike based on cthulu mythos. It also resembles Minecraft visually but doesn't have the same level of depth or complexity. I like the art style and was thrilled to see lovecraft monsters in chunky 3D. Initially there were some moments where there was a lot of tension in trying to creep around and find items... after a while though, it feels like the possibilities are exhausted. What I like about rogulikes are the randomness and the variety. There are always surprises and you might die in horrible ways but there is also a sense of progression. You 'level up' or find something unusual or rare and it makes the difficulty a little more bearable... you want to jump in and try again. After clearing a couple of maps in eldritch it didn't feel like things were progressing in a way that was engaging for me. I like the idea that you're a lone person and you're scrambling for a few scarce rescources against cthulus minions in strange alien environments, I like the visual style and a lot of the gameplay... it just feels like there's something missing (maybe a few things), that would make me want to keep coming back to the game. I would really like to see some mod support.
Good rogue like with a funny vision of cthulhu world

I was introduced to this game through Steam's family share and enjoyed every minute of it, start to finish.  I would definitely purchase it for myself and play it all again, if it weren't for the price.\n\nSo I sit and wait patiently for it to go on sale.

I don't really mean to give this a bad review, I just find the game really... meh.

We have a Call of Cthulhu themed stealthish RNG rouge-like where you have to pass 12 levels to win the game. First off, I'm a big lovecraft fan and a Call of Cthulhu writer, so I really appreciated the journals left around and I was very interested in the asylum portion of the game, just from a creative standpoint.

However, the gameplay leaves a lot to be desired and a lot of that comes from the format of the levels. You go through 3 maps to get souls of various gods. The problem is that every map is basically the same. Sure,  there's an underwater theme, a desert theme, and a davy jones/nautical theme, but in every map, you have one goal, find your way to the exit at the bottom. You have to race to the bottom 3 times per themed area, which means you have to successfully pass 12 maze maps before you can even attempt the finale. With that, its no wonder that only 4.5% of all players who bought this game have actually finished it. Not to mention that to get the best ending, you need to find 3 sacred items that are hidden somewhere within the 12 levels before the finale. Because of the level design, I barely find myself sneaking and instead just race to the bottom as fast as possible it works 66% of the time.

Additionally, I found the combat to be too easy 66% of the time, negating the purpose of sneaking all together. Why so specific? The Cthulhu and Dagon themed areas have really easy enemies. Deep Ones, Cultists, and Star-spawn will usually either kill themselves by accident or a knife is enough to kill all the enemies in a level without taking any damage. However, the Nytharlotep area is by far the hardest and can take hours just to get a single good run in. This is because the enemies are really non-standard. One enemy (of which there are many in a single level) is a mummy that can't be killed, only stunned. Another is a lizard statue that teleports to attack you if you stop looking at it. The problem then is that to finish the Nytharlotep area, you have to pass by a hall of lizard statues lined up like terra-cotta warriors. You can't look at them the whole time because the door they're guarding is locked most (if not all) the time and so your only hope is to find enough dynamite in the stage to get rid of them or have enough health points to take the hits. Its really frustrating to reach the bottom and then to die because of this one enemy type that will alwasy be at the end point.

Last note: I wish they had put in a different god than Dagon, because we've already seen Deep Ones in a Call of Cthulhu game before. I wish they had done something like Yog-Sothoth or some-such.

Anyway, again this isn't a bad review, its just... meh.

This game is all i've ever asked for in a stealth game

Its so simple yet so amazingly well done
Theres: leaning, throwing objects for distractions, backstabs, upgrades, shops, grapple launchers, tripwire guns, Pistols, + more
Its also voxel based (like minecraft) so you can blow up some of the terrain with tnt
You'll find a bunch of different enemies to face with different powers e.g. a stone statue that when disturbed turns into a weeping angel type thing. There is also a lot of more subtle abilities for enemies too, like shooting fireballs and stuff.


GET THIS GAME!!!

Eldritch is essentially Spelunky in first person that plays like Dishonored and looks like Minecraft. It's fun and engrossing, controls extremely well, and strikes a moody tone. I bought the game for a $1.50 but would have happily paid somewhere between $5 - $10.

A retro-styled 3d rogue-lite set in a twisted cthulhu-esque world.
You´re a female or male pulp hero set out to gather the souls of the old ones.
You´re doing so by reading ancient tomes in order to teleport to foreign planets and distant dimensions.
Or you can grind the mountains of madness or a halloween world.

You encounter fish-like frogs or frog-like fishes or star spawns or cultists or shoggoths and the like.
Then you´ll bury them one after another, collecting artifacts and ammo or spells to bury them even faster.
Except for the shoggoth-things. Those beasts can´t be killed. Or is it a dark young? I can´t tell anymore.

Then you casually walk to the 'Ye olde Mythos-Store' to buy or steal even more fancy loot and start all over.

Fluff Review:
Eldritch is a great game with a weird name. Even though this game never explains the origins of its name, it might be linked to the definition of the word: “weird / spooky”. This game certainly is spooky, and unique. The worlds you explore are randomly generated in this 1st person roguelike. The tactics you can employ can be as diverse or simple as you need. You can sneak up on people and stab them from behind for a critical hit, you can shoot from afar, or you can distract your enemies and never face them at all. Personally, I would summon Shaggoths (what look like giant furry heaps of hay painted green with bloody teeth and creepy eyes) and have them lash out at all of my enemies, whether it attacked baby cthulus, wizards, or lizardmen. I am somewhat ashamed to admit that I took a savage pleasure in strolling into a shop, talking to the clerk, and then summoning a mighty shaggoth to murder the clerk while I looted the store. But that is the beauty of the game. You can choose what you do, how you play, and risk your safety. The game is permadeath, so the penalty of getting hurt can be brutal. I played 36 hours before I beat the game, so my Dollar to Hour Ratio was 41 cents for every hour I played the game, which is great. The enemies you face are unique. Different species sometimes fight each other, wizards hate you, and Shaggoths want to kill everyone. Shaggoths are invincible, so I ended up adapting my strategy to locking them up in little huts I encountered. The difficulty can be, at times, brutal. I remember at one point being halfway through the game, and falling into a hole in which I could not get out of, and I was forced to restart my game. Once you play the game a lot, exploring can become repetitive. The end was very much a surprise, and not a good one. I liked where the story was going, but as it reached the climax, you click ‘f’ and the game is done, just like that!

Overall, I would give this game a thumbs up.

Legitimately one of my top 10 FPS games I've ever played. A mix of Doom and Stone Soup, this game will keep you captive in it's library for hours.

There are five six 'books' or stages, in this game. The first four (three + one) are for the normal game, the fifth is the 'Mountains of Madness' mentioned in the store page video, and the sixth is a place called the 'Asylum' [There is also a Halloween-themed bonus stage, wonder if you can find it. Great for farming artifacts]

You have four things on the upper left: Hearts represents health, Blue oval-shapes represent 'artifacts,' or the in-game currency, Green Keys are for unlocking doors, and Yellow Bullets are ammo for your revolver (no reload system, simply M1 until you run out)

There is a lot of holding 'shift' in this game (to run), especially for some of the achivements. Unfortunately, there is no toggle to run, unlike for crouching, but not really a big deal.

It is not a terribly difficult game. Enemies' projectiles miss often, especially when you are running, and circle strafing enemies while punching/knifing them will dispatch them quickly. For first-time players I would suggest a more cautious approach; my first complete run took about 1 hour 30 minutes.

After the inital novelty wears off, there is not much left except the same repeat of: evade/kill enemies, pick up items, move on to the next chapter. For that reason alone, I would not recommend at full price unless you enjoy this genre and/or the Lovecraftian theme. I am not familiar with the universe of H.P. Lovecraft, so I cannot comment on this game's accuracy to its source of inspiration

The redeeming factors that gives life and replayability to this game are the online leaderboards and steam achivements. For those who embrace challenge and enjoy testing their limits, perhaps this game is for you

Eldritch is a really nice little game. The gameplay is fluent and there are some creepylooking monsters to kill. But I have two little complaints for the game. Firstly I wish there are more weapons, I get it that you only have one arm to use them, so shotguns and machine guns are out, but I would have at least liked a flare gun or another pistol. Secondly the enemey respawns can get annoying sometimes. But I definiteley recommend this game (I later found out that you can stop them from respawning by simply not looting their corpses)

The graphic may scare possible players off but because of the game´s pixelated look runs smooth like butter. Also worth a mention is the game´s soundtrack, it´s just great, really atmospheric and it sets the mood perfectly. The randomly generated levels are a blast to play, I personally really liked the second book and the mountains of madness free DLC area. These levels often include a nice gimmick, for example tiles that crumble when you step on them or invicible enemies. The levels often end with a special building, that really looks quite impressing and stands out from all the randomly generated stuff you have seen throughout the level.

Speaking of randomly generated, this feature works surprisingly well. I have never seen any weird constructions during my playthrough and the game still has a feel of leveldesign even though it actually shouldn´t be there.

To sum it up I would definiteley recommend this game. It took me about 20 hours to get through the whole game (visiting every area and dying sometimes) and nearly every minute was great and tense fun!

Also the game includes one of the best snow levels I have played in a long while ;)

(for a more serious take on the Lovecraftian mythos you should check out the long forgotten Shadow of the comet" and "Prisoner of ice" and the more popular "Dark corners of the earth")"
